TRANSLATION.



Hail ! Prosperity !••••••••••1444In the 3rd year (of the reign) of king Rājakēsarivarman, alias the lord Śrī-Rājēndra-Śōl6adēva, who was pleased to take his seat on the throne of heroes together with (his queen), the mistress of the whole world,--we, the great assembly of Sōmaṅgalam, alias Rājaśikhāmaṇi-chaturvēdi-maṅgalam, in Māgaṇūr-nāḍu, (a subdivision) of Śēṅgāṭṭu-kōṭṭam, (a district) of Jayaṅgoṇḍa-Śōl6a-maṇḍalam, drew up the following writing on stone, to last as long as the moon, in favour of the lord of the holy Chitrakūṭa (temple) in our village•••• ••••••


No. 68.--INSCRIPTION IN THE PANDAVA-PERUMAL TEMPLE.



This inscription (No. 17 of 1893) is engraved on the north wall of the Pāṇḍava-Peru-māḷ temple at Conjeeveram. The ancient name of the temple was Tiruppāḍagam (l. 3), and it is mentioned under the name of Pāḍagam in the Nālāyiraprabandham.
The date is the 5th year of the king, who is now styled Kulōttuṅga-Chōḷadēva (I.), while in the inscriptions of his 2nd, 3rd and 4th years (Nos. 64 to 67 and 77) he still bears the name Rājēndra-Chōḷadēva (II.).
The new inscription refers to his early victories at Śakkarakōṭṭam and Vayi-rāgaram.1445 It then states that he vanquished the king of Kuntala, i.e. the Western Chālukya king Vikramāditya VI., that he crowned himself as king of the country on the banks of the Kāvērī, i.e. of the Chōḷa country, and that he decapitated an unnamed Pāṇḍya king. An inscription of the 6th year of his reign1446 adds nothing new to these[page 3-141]
The subjoined inscription records that a merchant of Kāñchipuram provided the temple with a flower-garden and purchased from the villagers of Ōrirukkai some land for the benefit of the gardeners. I cannot find Ōrirukkai on the map; but it must be looked for near Uttiramēlūr1447 (l. 4) in the Madurāntakam tāluka of the Chingleput district. As boundaries of the land granted, the inscription mentions also the river Al6ichchiyāṟu and apparently the village of Śāttamaṅgalam. A village of this name1448 I find 8 miles east of Madurāntakam.


TEXT.



1 svasti SrI [||*] [pu]kaz cUznta puNari akaz cUznta puviyil p[o]n_nemi-yaLavuntan_ nemi naTAtti viLagku jayamakaLai iLagkop[pa]ruvattu cakkarakoT-Tattu vikkiramattozi[lA*]l putumaNam puNar nta1449 van_kaLiRRiTTa[m*]1450vayi-rAkarattu vAri ayilmun_aikkontaLavaraicar tantanamiri[ya] vALuRai kazittu toL vali kATTi porppari na[T]Atti1451kirttiyai niRutti vaTaticai vA-kai cUTitten_Ricai[t]temarukamalap[pU]makaL1452putumaiyum pon_niyATai(yum) nan_nilappAvaiyunta n_imaiyuntavirttu14531454punitaru[tiru]maNimaku-
2 -muRaim[ai]yil cUTi tan_[na]Tiyira[N]Tum taTamuTi[yA]ka [t]onnilav[e]ntar [cUTa]ppo[n_]ni matuvARu [p]e[ru]ka kaliy[A]Ru vaRappa ce[g]kol ticai-toRuñcel[la] veNkuTai irunilavaL[A]kam[e]gkaNuntanAtu tiruni[la]veN-NilAttikaza orutani meruvil puli viLaiyATa [Az]kaTaR[RI]vAntarattu pUvar tiRai vi[Tu]tta kala[n_] co[ri*] kaLiRu muRai ni[R]pa viLagkiya tennavana-runtalai paruntalaittukkiTappa [na]n_maNiyAramuntirup[pu]yattalagkalum1455 tana[tu] 1456viramu[nti]yAkamu[m] viLagka pArmicai meva[la]r vaNagka 3-141-10>virasiMhAsanattu puvanamuzutuTaiyALoTum [vI]RRi-
3 runtaruLiya k[o] rAjak[E]sari[vatma]rAna uTaiyAr SrIkulottugkacozadEva- [R]ku yANTu añcAvatu [|| § ||] jayagkoNTacozamaNTalattukkAliyUrkko-TTattukkAliyUrnATTu ori[ru]kkai Urom zilAlekai ceytu kuTutta paricAvatu [|*] eyiRkoTTatteyilnATTu nakaragkurañcipurattu1457 arumozite-vapperuntEruvil viyApAri kumAra[p]peruvANiyan_ teva[n_] eRiñcoTiyAka aruLALadAsan_ tiruppATakattezuntaruLiyirunta AzvA[nu]kkucceyta tirunanta- n_avanam koyilil tiruppuRakkuTaiyil1458
4 aru[L]ALadAsanen_num tirun_antan_ava[n_a]muzapp[Ar]kkukkoRRukku[m1459 pu]Tavai [mu]talukku[m] nibandhañ[c]e[yya] nAgkaL iRaiyizicci egkaLuril1460 viRRu-kkuTutta [ni]lamAvatu [|*]1461kizpARkellai u[tti]ramelUrAr vatikku meRku- ntEnpARkellai azicciyARRukku vaTakkum mel[p]AR[k]ellai [ti]ru[v]e-[aH*]kAvAzv[A]nukku nAgka[L] viRRa nila[t]tukkum cAttamagkalamuTai[y]An_ kaTakan_ ceRuvukkum kizakkum vaTapARkellai cAttamagkalamuTaiyAn_ kaTiccA-ñceRukkuNTilukkutteRkum [|*] innAn_kellaiyu-
5 [L]LumakappaTTa uNNilamozivin_Rippa[ti]naRucAN k[o]lAl kuziyiraNTAyara-mu[m1462 vi]RRu inn_ilattukku vilaip[p]oruLivan_ pakkal koNTa p[o]n_
[page 3-142] [ma]turAntakan_ mATaiy[o]To[k]ka kuTi naRkallAl niRai pa[ti]noru-[kaza]ñcu[m] aRakkoNTu iRaiyi[li] tevatAnamAkki innilat[tu]kku v[e]- likkAcuma1463ni[rvi]lai[yu]m cilliRai co[Ru]mATTuL[Li]TTu epp[e]rppaTTa-tum kATTa[p]p[eRA]tomAkavum [|*] in[ni]la[m]An_aikkaRukkil aRutta1464kala-ttAl [vanta] nel[lu] AzvAn SrIpa[NT]Aratte aLappomAkavu[m |*] [i]nnilattakappa-
6 TTa kAlvAy ki[zak]kuL[La] nilattukku [nI]r pA[ya]ppeRu[va]tAkavu[m] [|*] ipparicu icaintu candrAtittavaRcella [ci]lAlekai ceytu kuTuttom o-ri[ru]kkai Urom [|*] ivarkaL colla ezutinen iv[vU]r veLLALan cAttamagkalamuTai[y]An veLAn kayi[lA]yatten1465[|*] ivai ennezuttu [|| § ||] SrIvaiSNavarakSai || § ||--


TRANSLATION.



(Line 1.) Hail ! Prosperity ! Having made the wheel of his (authority) to go as far as the golden circle (i.e). Mount Mēru) on the earth, which was surrounded by the moat of the sea, that was (again) surrounded by (his) fame, (the king) newly wedded, in the time (when he was still) heir-apparent (iḷaṅgō), the brilliant goddess of victory at Śakkarakōṭṭam by deeds of valour and scized a herd of strong elephants at Vayirāgaram. (He) unsheathed (his) sword, showed the strength of (his) arm, and spurred (his) war-steed, so that the king of Kondaḷa (Kuntala), (whose spear had) a sharp point, lost his wealth. Having established (his) fame, having put on the garland of (the victory over) the Northern region, and having stopped the prostitution of the goddess with the sweet and excellent lotus-flower (i.e. Lakshmī) of the Southern region, and the loneliness of the goddess of the good country whose garment is the Poṉṉi (Kāvērī), (he) put on by right (of inheritance) the pure royal crown of jewels, while the kings of the old earth bore his two feet (on their heads) as a large crown.
(L. 2.) The sweet river Poṉṉi swelled, (and) the river (of the sins) of the Kali (age) dried up. (His) sceptre swayed over every region; the heavenly1466 white light of (his) white parasol shone everywhere on the circle of the great earth; (and his) tiger(-banner) fluttered unrivalled on the Mēru (mountain). (Before him) stood a row of elephants showering jewels, which were presented (as) tribute by the kings of remote islands of the deep sea. The excellent head of the brilliant king of the South (i.e. the Pāṇḍya) lay being pecked by kites. While his valour and liberality shone like (his) necklace of precious stones and (like) the flower-garland on (his) royal shoulders, (and) while (all his) enemies prostrated themselves on the ground, (he) was pleased to take his seat on the throne of heroes together with (his queen), the mistress of the whole world.
(L. 3.) In the fifth year (of the reign) of this king Rājakēsarivarman, alias) the lord Śrī-Kulōttuṅga-Śōl6adēva,--we, the inhabitants of Ōrirukkai in Kāliyūr-nāḍu, (a subdivision) of Kāliyūr-kōṭṭam,1467 (a district) of Jayaṅgoṇḍa-Śōl6a-maṇḍalam, made and gave the following writing on stone:--Kumāra-Peruvāṇiyaṉ1468 Dēvaṉ Eṟiñjōḍi,[page 3-143] alias Aruḷāḷadāsaṉ,1469 a merchant (residing) in the great street of Arumolidēva1470 at Kāñchipuram, a city in Eyil-nāḍu, (a subdivision) of Eyiṟkōṭṭam,1471 had made for the god who is pleased to reside in the Tiruppāḍagam (temple) a flower-garden, called the flower-garden of Aruḷāḷadāsaṉ (and situated) on the outside of the temple. In order to provide for the cost (mudal) of the clothing of those who work (in this garden) and of (their) families, we sold the following land in our village free from taxes.
(L. 4.) The eastern boundary (is) to the west of the road of the inhabitants of Uttira-mēlūr; the southern boundary (is) to the north of the Al6ichchiyāṟu (river); the western boundary (is) to the cast of the land which we have sold to (the temple of) Tiruve[ḥ]kāvāl6-vāṉ1472 and of the field of Śāttamaṅgalam-Uḍaiyāṉ Kaḍagaṉ; and the northern bound-ary (is) to the south of the small field of Śāttamaṅgalam-Uḍaiyāṉ Kaḍichchāṉ. Having sold the two thousand kul6i, (measured) by the rod of sixteen spans,1473 enclosed in these four boundaries, not excluding the cultivated land, (we) received from him1474 as purchase-money for this land eleven kal6añju of gold, weighed by the true standard of the city (kuḍi-naṟ-kal) (and) equal (in fineness) to the Madurāntakaṉ-māḍai.1475 Having received (this amount) in full and having made (the land) a tax-free dēvadāna), we shall not be able to claim on this land vēlikkāśu,1476 water-cess (nīr-vilai), petty taxes,1477 śōṟumāṭṭu1478 and any other (tax).
(L. 5.) We have to measure into the treasury of the temple the paddy which comes from the land harvested in Āṉaikkaṟukku, (a portion of ?) this land. It shall be lawful to irrigate the land lying to the east (of the land sold), from the channels included in this land.
(L. 6.) Having thus agreed, we, the inhabitants of Ōrirukkai, made and gave (this) writing on stone to continue as long as the moon and the sun. At the bidding of these, I, Śāttamaṅgalam-Uḍaiyāṉ Vēḷāṉ Kayilāyatt[āṉ], a cultivator of this village, wrote (this). This is my writing. (This is placed under) the protection of the Śrī-Vaishnavas.


No. 69.--INSCRIPTION AT TIRUKKALUKKUNRAM.



This inscription (No. 174 of 1894) is engraved on the wall of the strong-room of the Vēdagirīśvara temple at Tirukkal6ukkuṉṟam, a large village in the Chingleput district on the road from Chingleput to the port of Sadras.1479 This village is mentioned in Sundaramūrti's Dēvāram as Kal6ukkuṉṟam, 'the hill of the kites.' The ancient name of the temple was Mūlasthāna.1480 Tirukkal6ukkuṉṟam itself bore the surname Ulagaḷanda-Śōl6apuram and belonged to Kaḷattūr-nāḍu, a subdivision of the district of Kaḷattūr-kōṭṭam. The names of this district and of its subdivision are derived from Kalattūr, a village on the south of Chingleput.1481
[page 3-144]
The inscription records the grant of two lamps, made in the 14th and 15th years of the reign of Kulōttuṅga I. (ll. 32 and 38). The historical introduction agrees on the whole with that of No. 68 as far as line 11. It then relates that Kulōttuṅga I. drove Vikkalan (i.e. Vikramāditya VI.) from Naṅgili (in the Kōlār district)1482 by way of Maṇalūr1483 to the Tuṅgabhadrā river, and that he conquered the Gaṅga-maṇḍalam and Śiṅgaṇam, by which the dominions of Jayasiṁha III. seem to be meant.1484 Having secured his frontiers in the north, he turned against the Pāṇḍyas1485 and subdued the south-western portion of the peninsula as far as the Gulf of Maṉṉār, the Podiyil mountain (in the Tinnevelly district), Cape Comorin, Kōṭṭāṟu, the Sahya (i.e. the Western Ghāṭs) and Kuḍamalai-nāḍu (i.e. Malabar). From the statement that he "fixed the boundary of the Southern country" (l. 27), it may be concluded that he limited the territories of the Pāṇḍya king to the Madura district. In order to pacify the newly acquired country, he settled some of his officers on the roads passing through Kōṭṭāṟu, etc. An inscription of the 39th year of his reign at Chōḷapuram, a portion of Kōttāṟu (No. 46 of 1896), actually mentions one of those military settlers.1486


TEXT.

29 toRuni[lai]kaLiTTaru[Li] tiRal k[oL] ci[gkAcana]ttu iruntaruLi pog-koLi-
30 [y]A[ramu]m tiruppuya[tta]lagkalum [pol vIramu]m tiyAkamu[m] viLagka p[A]r-
31 micai m[evala]r [vaNa]gka1514viRRiruntaruLi[ya] k[ovirA]jakecari[vanma]rAna cakkara[va]tti-
[page 3-146]
32 [ka]L SrIkulottu[g]kaco[za]dEvaRku [yANTu 1]4 Avatu jayagko-
33 NTac[oza]ma[NTala]ttukka[La]ttUrkk[o]TTattu kaLattUrnATTu ta[n_] kURRu dEvatAna[ntirukka]zu-
34 kku[n_]RamAna1515ulakaLantaco[zapura]ttu1516SrImulastAnamuTaiyamahAdEvaRku1517OymA-n_ATTu cevUr[Ana]
35 co[za]keraLanallUrirukku••• ppaLLi celvan_ pazumaTaiyan_Ana kulottu-gkacoza[p]p[eri]-
36 yarayan vaitta tirunu[nt]A[viLa]kku 1 on_Rinukku arumozitevanuzakkAl nica-tamuzakku ney[kku]
37 viTTa cA[vA mU]vApper[ATu t]oNNURu [|*] ivai cantrAdityavaraiy celu[ttu]v[An_] aTi en [ta]-
38 lai melina [|*] itu [panmAh]EzvararakSai [|*] meRpaTiyAn_ [y]ANTu 15 Avatu [v]ai[tta]
39 tirununtAviLakku•••• Ta1518 [ATu] toNNURum cAvA [mU]v[A]ppe-rATu [|*] iv[ai]y panm[Ah]EzvararakSai [||*]


TRANSLATION.



(Line 1.) Hail ! Prosperity ! While the wheel of his (authority) went as far as the golden circle (i.e. Mount Mēru) on the earth, which was surrounded by the moat of the sea, that was (again) surrounded by (his) fame, (the king) newly wedded, in the time (when he was still) heir-apparent, the brilliant goddess of victory at Śakkarakōṭṭam by deeds of valour and seized a herd of mountains of rut (i.e). rutting elephants) at Vayirāgaram.
(L. 3.) (He) unsheathed (his) sword, showed the strength of (his) arm, and spurred (his) war-steed, so that the army of the king of Kondaḷa, (whose spear had) a sharp point, retreated.
(L. 4.) Having established (his) fame, having put on the garland of (the victory over) the Northern region, and having stopped the prostitution of the goddess with the sweet and excellent lotus-flower (i.e. Lakshmī) of the Southern region, and the loneliness of the goddess of the good country whose garment is the Poṉṉi, (he) put on by right (of inheritance) the pure royal crown of jewels, while the kings of the earth bore his two feet (on their heads) as a large crown.
(L. 6.) The river (of the rules) of the ancient king Manu swelled, (and) the river (of the sins) of the Kali (age) dried up.
(L. 7.) (His) sceptre swayed over every (quarter of) this continent of the nāval (tree); the white light of the sacred shadow of (his) white parasol shone everywhere on the circle of the great earth; (and his) tiger (-banner) fluttered unrivalled on the Mēru (mountain).
(L. 9.) (Before him) stood a row of elephants showering jewels, which were presented (as) tribute by the kings of remote islands whose girdle is the sea.
(L. 10.) The excellent head of the refractory king of the South (i.e. the Pāṇḍya) lay outside his (viz. Kulōttuṅga's) beautiful city, being pecked by kites.
[page 3-147]
(L. 11.) Not only did the speech (of Vikkalaṉ):--"After this day a permanent blemish (will attach to Kulōttuṅga), as to the crescent1519 (which is the origin) of (his) family,"1520--turn out wrong, but the bow (in) the hand of Vikkalaṉ was not (even) bent against (the enemy).
(L. 13.) Everywhere from Naṅgili of rocky roads--with Maṇalūr in the middle--to the Tuṅgabhadrā, there were lying low the dead (bodies of his) furious elephants, his lost pride and (his) boasted valour.
(L. 14.) The very mountains which (he) ascended bent their backs; the very rivers into which (he) descended eddied and breached (the banks) in their course; (and) the very seas into which (he) plunged became troubled and agitated.
(L. 16.) (The Chōḷa king) seized simultaneously the two countries (pāṇi) called Gaṅga-maṇḍalam and Śiṅgaṇam, troops of furious elephants which had been irretrievably abandoned (by the enemy), crowds of women, (the angles of) whose beautiful eyes were as pointed as daggers, the goddess of fame, who gladly brought disgrace (on Vikkalaṉ), and the great goddess of victory, who changed to the opposite (side) and caused (Vikkalaṉ) himself and (his) father, who were desirous of the rule over the Western region, to turn their backs again and again on many days.
(L. 20.) Having resolved in (his) royal mind to conquer also the Pāṇḍi-maṇḍalam (i.e. the Pāṇḍya country) with great fame, (he) despatched his great army,--which possessed [excellent horses (resembling) the waves of the sea], war-elephants (resembling) ships, and troops (resembling) water,--as though the Northern ocean was overflowing the Southern ocean.
(L. 22.) (He) completely destroyed the forest which the five Pañchavas (i.e. Pāṇḍyas) had entered as refuge, when they were routed on a battlefield where (he) fought (with them), and fled cowering with fear.
(L. 24.) (He) subdued (their) country, drove them into hot jungles (in) hills where woodmen roamed about, and planted pillars of victory in every region.
(L. 25.) (He) was pleased to seize the pearl fisheries,1521 the Podiyil (mountain) where the three kinds of Tamil6 (flourished),1522 [the (very) centre of the (mountain) Śaiyam1523] where furious rutting elephants were captured, and Kaṉṉi,1524 and fixed the boundaries of the Southern (i.e. Pāṇḍya) country.
(L. 27.) While all the heroes1525 in the Western hill-country (Kuḍamalai-nāḍu)1526 ascended voluntarily to heaven, (he) was pleased to bestow on the chiefs of his army, who were mounted on horses, settlements on every road, including (that which passed) Kōṭṭāṟu,1527 in order that the enemies might be scattered, and took his seat on the throne acquired in warfare.
[page 3-148]
(L. 29.) (He) was pleased to be seated (on it) while (his) valour and liberality shone like (his) necklace of great splendour and (like) the flower-garland on (his) royal shoulders, (and) while (all his) enemies prostrated themselves on the ground.
(L. 31.) In the [1]4th year (of the reign) of this king Rājakēsarivarman, alias the emperor Śrī-Kulōttuṅga-Śōl6adēva, 1--one--perpetual lamp was given to Mahādēva, the lord of the Śrī-Mūlasthāna (temple) at Tirukkal6ukkuṉṟam, alias Ulagaḷanda-Śōl6apuram, a dēvadāna) in its own circle (kūṟu)1528 in Kaḷattūr-nāḍu, (a subdivision) of Kaḷattūr-kōṭṭam, (a district) of Jayaṅgoṇḍa-Śōl6a-maṇḍalam, by •••• ppaḷḷi Śelvaṉ Pal6umaḍaiyaṉ, alias Kulōttuṅga-Śōl6a-periyarayaṉ, who resided at Śēvūr,1529 alias Śōl6akēraḷanallūr, in Ōymāṉāḍu.1530
(L. 36.) In order (to supply) to (this lamp) one ul6akku of ghee per day, (measured) by the Arumol6idēvaṉ-ul6akku,1531 (he) granted ninety full-grown ewes, which must neither die nor grow old.1532
(L. 37.) The feet of him who will continue this (grant) as long as the moon and the sun exist, shall be on my head. This (is placed under) the protection of all Māhēśvaras).
(L. 38.) In the 15th year (of the king's reign) the above-mentioned person (also) granted ninety full-grown ewes, which must neither die nor grow old, for 1 (other) perpetual lamp which (he) had given. This (is placed under) the protection of all Māhēśvaras.


No. 70.--INSCRIPTION AT SRIRANGAM.



This inscription (No. 62 of 1892) is engraved on the east wall of the third prākāra of the Raṅganātha temple1533 on the island of Śrīraṅgam near Trichinopoly. It mentions Śrīraṅgam as Tiruvaraṅgam (l. 16) and the temple as Tiruvaraṅgadēvar (l. 10).
The date is the 18th year of the reign of Kulōttuṅga I. The historical introduction does not add any fresh details to those narrated at the beginning of the inscriptions of the 14th and 15th years1534. The inscription records that a certain Kāliṅgarāyar granted to the temple 6(1/4) kāśu with the condition that the interest should be applied to defraying the cost of offerings on two festival days.
As discovered by Mr. Venkayya,1535 the subjoined inscription fixes the time before which two of the twelve Vaishṇava Āl6vārs, who were the authors of the Nālāyiraprabandham, must have lived. For, (1) it refers to the recital of the text beginning with Tēṭṭarundiṟal (l. 13), which is the 2nd chapter of the sacred hymns of Kulaśēkhara; and (2) the names of three of the temple officials who are mentioned in the inscription prove that the Vaishṇava saint Śaṭhagōpa or Nammāl6vār was already at that time well known and highly venerated.1536 As noticed before, his work, the Tiruvāymol6i, is presupposed already in an inscription of Rājarāja I.1537 These epigraphical evidences are fatal to the theory of Dr. Caldwell, who placed the Āl6vārs in the 12th or 13th century.1538
[page 3-149]

TEXT.



1 svasti SrI [||] pu[ka]z cUznta puNari [a]kaz cUznta [pu]1539••• [p][on_]- ne[mi]ya[Lavuntan] nemi naTappa vi[La]gku jayamakaLai iLagkopparuvattu ca[ka]- karakoTTat[tu vi]k[ki]ramatto[za]lAl putumaNam puNar[n*]tu1540ma[tu]va[r]ai-[yI]TTam vayirA[karat]tu vAri ayirmu[n_ai]kko[n]taLavaracar tan taLamiri[ya v]ALuRai kazittuttoL vali kAT[Ti]ppo[rp]pari naTAttik[ki]r[t]tiyai1541
2 [ni]Rutti vaTaticai vAkai cUTitte1542•••• ma[ruka]ma[la]ppUmakaL potu-maiyum ponniyATai na[n_]nilappAvai tanimaiyuntavira vantu1543punitaRtirumaNi-makuTam u[ri]maiyiRcUTitta[n_]naTi iraNTum taTamuTiyAkattonnilaventar [cU]Ta munn_ai [ma]nu[v]ARu peruka kaliyA-
3 Ru vaRu[ppa]ccegkol ticai[t]oRu[ñ]1544••••• [ku]Tai [i]ru[ni]la-vaLAkam egkaNu[nta]nAtu tirunizal v[e]NNilAttikaza orutani meruviRpuli vi[Lai]yA[Ta]1545vArkaTaRRivAntarattuppUpAlar tiRai viTutanta kalañcori kaLiRu muRai ni[R]pa vilagki[ya t]ena[nava]n karu[nta]lai paru[nta]lai-

5 paTTa vegkaLiRum viT[Ta] tan mA[na]mug[kURi]na1548viramug[ki]Ta[ppa] e[Ri]na malaikaLumutuku ne[Li]ppa izinta nati[ka]Lu1549••• nRuTaintoTa [vi]zunta kaTalkaLuntalaivirittalamara[k]kuTaticaitta[nnA]Lu[ka]ntu tAnu[m] t[An_aiyum] pan-nALiTTa pa[la]pala mu[tu]ku pa[ya]tte[ti]r mARa1550 ja-

7 LLattaTait[tu] veLLa[va]ruparittaragkaLum1554 poru••• kkulagka•• tantira-vAriyum uTaittAy vantu vaTakaTal tenkaTal paTa[r]vatu polattan peru-ñcen_ai evippañcavar aiyvarum [p]oruta moykkaLattañci veru noLit-te1555•••••••••• ttu-
8 Taittu1556nAnaTippa[Tu]ttu maRRavartammai vanacarar tiriyum poR[R*]ai [ve]- ñcurameRRikakoRRavijaiyasta[mpa]m ticait[o]1557••• tti mutti[na] calApamumuttamiTpotiyilumattaveg[kari] pa[Tu]maiyyaccayyamugkanni[yu]gkaik-ko[N]••••••••••
9 1558kaTalmalai[n]A[T]Tu[L]La cAveRe[l]lAm tani [vi]cump[e]Ra mAveRiya [ta]n 1559va[rukaniR]Ralai[va]r[ai]••• kalar1560 kulaiyakkoTTARuTpaTa ne[Ri]toRu-
[page 3-150] [ni]laika[Li]TTaru[Li]t[ti]Rai koL [vI]rasiMhA[sa]kantiriya viTTaruLip-p[og]ko[Li]yAramunti[ru]p[pu]ya[tta]ragka[Lu]m1561 poliya [vI]ramu[ntiyA]kamum [vi]LagkappArmicai mevalar va•• ka1562 [vI]R[Ri]runtaru[Li]ya
10 kovirAjakesaripanmarAna [ca]kravattika[L] SrIkolottugkaco[za]dEvaRku yA[N]1563•••• naTTAvatu [§] AzvAr [ti]ruvaragkatevarkku SrIkAri-yañceykiRa ati[kA]rikaL niSa[ta]rAjar Eval paTiyum SrIva[yi]SNa[va*]vAriyam [ti]ruvezu[ti]nATudAsa[ru]m vaTamaturappiRantAnampiyum irAyUrA[Li]na[m]piyum ••• [r] nArA[ya]Nanampi-

12 n SrI[kR]SNanum1566 pAritan1567 [A]rAva[mu]tu 3-150-5>cirAmanum sabhaikkaNak[ku] arayan ampala•••••••• RRuvappiriyanum SrIvayiSNavakkaNakku tiruveg-kaTavan comanAna [pa]tineTTunATukizavanum uLLiTTa Az[va]•••1568nmika-Lom [a]ra[ya]n [garu]Da[v]AhanAna kAligkarAyarkku nAgkaL samma[ti]ttu-ttiTTukku•••1569 pari[c]Avatu [|*]
13 [a]p[pi]kai [t]erttirunA[Lilu]m pagkU[ni]t[ti]runA[Li]lum [tI]rttam pira[s]A- tittaru[Li]na [a]n[Ri]rA [ti]ruppun[n]aikkiz1570 ezuntaruLi iruntu teTTaru- ntiRal keTTa[ruLu]m [p]otu [iRR]ai nALAl tirunAL onRukku amuti ceytaruLum appamutu nURu[k]ku veN[Tu]m pazavarici patakkum paruppu mu nnAziyum ney munnA[zi]yu[m] caRka-
14 r[ai nU]RRu[p]palamum miLaku muzAkkum ci[ra]kam1571 uz[Ak]kum uppu muzAk-kum vAzai[p]pazam [ai]mpatum tegkAy aiñcum iLaniramutu1572 pattuma aTaikkAyamutu nURRirupatum kaRpUratapilam1573 oruceviTaraiyum terii[lai]p-paRRu panni[raN]Tum kaR[pU]ra[m] iraN[Tu] mañcATiyum appamutukku mAvi-TippArkkuniraTTuvAr-1574
15 k[kum vi]Raki[Tu]vAr[k]kum appamutu cu[Tu]vA[r]kkum1575ku•[ka]lattukkum uL-LiTTu maRRum veNTu[va]navaiyiRRukku1576•• ntirAti[t]taval cella ivar oTukkina kAcu ARe kAl [|*] ikkAcu ARe kAlugkoNTu policaiyAl ira[N]Tu ti[ru]nA[Lilu]m ippaTiyey cantirAtittaval amuti ce[y]vikkak-kaTavomAka-
16 vum [|*] ippaTi kal veTTi[vi]ttukko[LLa]ppe••••• [vu]m [|*] ip[paTi i]caintu 1577sammAtatti[T]TukkuTutt[o]m [A]zvAr kanmikaLom [|*] itu cantirAtittaval [c]e[lu]ttu[vi]kka [ka]TapomAnom1578 tiruvarag-kat[tu] mahAsa[bhai]yom [|*] itu SrIvayiSNavarakSai [||--]
[page 3-151]

TRANSLATION.



(Line 10.) In the [eighteenth] year (of the reign) of king Rājakēsarivarman, alias the emperor Śrī-Kulōttuṅga-Śōl6adēva, who etc.1579--by order of the magistrate (adhikārin) Nisha[dha]rājar, the manager of the temple of the god Tiruvaraṅgadēvar, the following was agreed on and given in writing to Arayaṉ[Garu]ḍa[v]āhaṉ, alias Kāliṅgarāyar, by us, the Pūjāris (kaṉmi) of the god, such as (1) the members of the committee1580 of the Śrī-Vaishṇavas: Tiruvel6u[di]nāḍu-Dāsar,1581 Vaḍamadurappiṟan-dā[ṉ]-1582 Nambi, Irāyūrā[ḷi]-Nambi,••••• r Nārāyaṇa-Nambi, Śrīśaḍa-gōpa-Dāsar1583 of Perum[ba]ṟṟappuliyūr, and Arikulavāraṇa-Nambi of Mārkka-maṅgalam; (2) the members of the committee of the temple treasury: Kurugaikāvalaṉ1584 Ārāvamudu of the Hārita (gōtra), Tiruvāykkulam-Uḍaiyāṉ1585 Śrīrāghavaṉ of the Hārita (gōtra), Kēśuvaṉ (Kēśava) [Ta]ni-Iḷa[ñ]jiṅgam of the Hārita (gōtra), Kēśuvaṉ Aṟivariyāṉ of the Bhāradvāja (gōtra), [Tiru]va[raṅ]ga-Nārāyaṇaṉ Śrīkṛshṇaṉ of the Bhāradvāja (gōtra), and Ārāvamudu Śrīrāmaṉ of the [H]ārita (gōtra); (3) the account-ants of the assembly: Arayaṉ Ambala••••• and ••••• āṟṟuvap-piriyaṉ; and (4) the accountant of the Śrī-Vaishṇavas: Tiruvēṅgaḍavaṉ1586 Sōmaṉ, alias Padineṭṭunāḍu-Kil6avaṉ.1587
(L. 13.) During the car festival in (the month of) Appigai (Aippaśi) and during the festival in Paṅgūni (Paṅguṉi), on the night of that day on which the bathing-water (of the idol) is distributed, at the time when (the idol) has been placed under the sacred puṉṉai (tree) and is listening to (the recital of the hymn) Tēṭṭarundiṟal, (the following requirements have to be supplied) on this day of either festival:--For one hundred cakes to be offered (to the god) are required one padakku of old rice, three nāl6i of pulse (paruppu), three nāl6i of ghee, one hundred palam of sugar, three ul6ākku of pepper, one ul6ākku of cumin, three ul6ākku of salt, fifty plantains, five cocoa-nuts, ten young cocoa-nuts, one hundred and twenty areca-nuts, one śeviḍu and a half of camphor-oil, twelve bundles of teri1588 leaves, and two mañjāḍi of camphor. (For all this), for those who pound (the rice into) flour for the cakes, for those who carry water, for those who fetch firewood, for those who fry the cakes, for pots, and for other requirements, he1589 deposited six and a quarter kāśu, to continue as long as the moon and the sun.
(L. 15.) Having received these six and a quarter kāśu, we shall be bound to supply the offerings in this way at both festivals out of the interest for as long as the moon and the sun[page 3-152] shall exist. Thus [it should be] caused to be engraved on stone. Having agreed thus, we, the Pūjāris of the god, gave a written agreement.
(L. 16.) We, the great assembly of Tiruvaraṅgam, shall be bound to continue this as long as the moon and the sun exist. This (is placed under) the protection of the Śrī-Vaishṇavas.


No. 71.--INSCRIPTION AT KILAPPALUVUR.



This inscription (No. 105 of 1895) is engraved on the west wall of the second prākāra of the Vaṭamūlēśvara temple at Kīl6appal6uvūr in the Uḍaiyārpāḷaiyam tāluka of the Trichinopoly district.1590 This village is mentioned under the name of Pal6uvūr in Tiruñāṉa-sambandar's Dēvāram. The subjoined inscription calls it both Śiṟupal6uvūr (ll. 18, 23, 25) and simply Pal6uvūr (ll. 26, 27). It belonged to Kuṉṟa-kūṟṟam, a subdivision of the district of Uttoṅgatoṅga-vaḷanāḍu (l. 18). According to other inscriptions at Kīl6appal6uvūr, the name of the Śiva temple was Tiruvālanduṟai-Mahādēva, in which āl, 'the banyan,' is the Tamil equivalent of vaṭa, the first member of Vaṭamūlēśvara, the Sanskrit designation of the temple. A Vishṇu temple at the same village, which was named Vīra-Śōl6a-Viṇṇa-gar, is mentioned in line 28 of the subjoined inscription.
The date is the 20th year of the reign of Kulōttuṅga I., when the assembly of Śiṟupal6uvūr sold one twentieth vēli of land for one kāśu to the mother of a certain Viruda-rājabhayaṁkara-Vāṇakōvaraiyar. This may have been the chief of Vāṇakōppāḍi, a district which is mentioned in an inscription at Tirukkōvalūr (No. 126 of 1900). That he received his title from Kulōttuṅga I., follows from the first portion of his name, Viruda-rājabhayaṁkara, which, according to the Kaliṅgattu-Paraṇi (x. verse 25), was a surname of Kulōttuṅga I. Another derivative of the same surname is the district of Virudarāja-bhayaṁkara-vaḷanāḍu; Gaṅgaikoṇḍachōḷapuram and Tirumudukuṉṟam (i.e. Vṛddhā-chalam in the South Arcot district) belonged to Mēṟkā-nāḍu, a subdivision of this district.1591 A Telugu inscription of Kulōttuṅga I. mentions Manni-nāṇḍu as another sub-division of the same district.1592


TEXT.



1 svasti SrI [||*] pukaz cUznta pu[Na]ri acaz cU[z*]n[ta] puvi[yi]l pon-nemiyaLavum tan nemi naT(A)[p]pa vi[Lag]ku j[e]yamaka[Lai] iLagkopparu-vat[tu]ccakka-
2 rakoTTattu vikkira[ma]ttozilAl pu[tu]ma[Na]m puNarntu1593matuva[r]aiyIT-Tam vayirAkarat[tu v]Ari a[yinun]ai[k]ko[n]ta[La]va[r]ai[ca]r ta[n] taLami-riya vALuRai kazi[t]-
3 tuttoL vali kATTipporppari naTAtti1594kirttiyai niRutti vaTa[ti]cai v[A]kai cUTi tentic[ai t]emarukamalappUma[kaL] po[tu]maiyum ponni-yA[T]ai(yum)
4 nann_ilappAvai ta[ni]mai[yu]m tavara vantu 1595punitaRti[ruma]NimakuTam [u]rimaiyiRc-cUTi tann_aTi iraNTum taTamuTiyAkattonnilaventar cUTa [mu][n_*][n_ai] manuva-
5 tu1596 perug[ka]liyARu [va]Ruppa cegkol ticaitoRum cella veNku[T]ai 1597irunilaviLAkammegkaNuntan_atu tirunizal (veNkuTai) ve[NNi]lA[t]ti-
[page 3-153]
6 kaza [oru]tani meruviRpuli [vi]LaiyATa vArkaTal tIvA[nta]rattu pUpAlar tiRai viTutta kalañcori raLu1598 muRaimuRai [ni]Rppa vilagkiya t[e]nn_a-va[na] karu[n*]talai pa[ru]ntalai-
7 tti--tan1599ponakkarppuRattiTaikkiTappa iññAL piRkulappiRai pol niRp-pizai[v]en[ni]lum1600 colletirkkoTiRRallatu tan kai vil[l]etir ko-
8 TA vikkalan kallatar na[g]kili [tu]Tagki maNalUr naTuvin tu(Ta)gkapattirai-yaLavuRRu le[g]kaNum1601 paTTa vegkaLuRu1602 viTTa tan mA[n_a]mug[kURi]ya [vI]ramugkiTappa eRi-
9 na malai[ka]Lum mutuku neLip[pa] izi[nta] na[ti]ka[Lum] cuzanRuTai[nt]OTa [vizunta] kaTalkaLum talaivirintalamara16031604kuTa[tac]ait[tan]nATucantu1605 tAnum tA-naiyum pan[n]ALITTa(mum)1606 pala-
10 pala mutu[ku*]m pa[ya]ntEtir mARiya jayapperuntiru[vu]m1607vALAloNkaN maTantaiyarITTamu[m] mi[L]A[tu]1608 kuTutta vegkari niraiyum kagkama[N]Tala-mu[m] cigka[Na]mennum p[A]Ni ir-
11 ATum1609 oruvi[cai]k[k]aikkoNTu iNaiviyappukazoTum pANTi[maN]Talagko-[L]La1610tiruviLattaTaittaruLi1611m[au]varuparit[ta]lagkaLum1612 poruparittalagka-

14 ti[c]aitoRum niRutti muttin ci[l]Apamum muttamuz1615 potiyalum mattave-gkari paTu[m]aiyatateyvavamum1616 kanni[yu]m kaikkoNTaruLi tennATTelai
15 kATTi kuTamalainATTuL[La cAve]R[el]lAntani vicumpeRa mAveRiya tan 1617varuta[vi]ttalai[va]rai kuRukalar kulaiya koTTARuLp[pa]Ta neRitoRum nilaika(L)[Li]TTaru[Li ti]Ra[l]
16 koL vIrasi[M]hA[sa]nam tiri[ya*] vi[T]Taru[Li] pogkoLiyAramum tirup-puyattalag[ka]Lum1618 pol vIramu[m] ti[y]Akamum viLag[ka] p[A*]rmicai mevalar vaNagka vIrasiMhAsanattu a-
17 vanimuzutuTaiyA(L)L[o]Tum vI[R]Rirun[ta]ruLiya ko rA[ja]kecari[vanma]rAna [ti]ripuva[n_a]ccak[ka]rava[tti]kaL SrIkolottug[ka]cozatevarkku [y]ANTu irupatAva-
18 tu uttogkat[o]gka[vaLa]n[A]TTukkunRakkURRattu brahmat[e]ya[m] ci[Rupa]zuvUr [sa]bhaiyom vi[ru*]tarAjapayagkaravANac[ova]raiyar tagka[L]LAcci [c]oza-kulacu ntaranviccA-
19 tiriyA[z]vArkku sabhaivilaiyAka viRRukkuTutta nilamA[va]tu [|*] rAjEntra- [c]ozavA[y*]kkAlukku vaTakku pavitti[ram]ANikkavatikkukkizakku mutal kaN-NARRu iraN-
[page 3-154]
20 TAm caturat[tu] ni[la]m nA[lum]Avil vaTakkaTaiy nilam orumAvil1619ki[z]k-kaTaiy nilam a[r]ai[m]Avum ivvatikkukkizakku i[v]vA[y*]kkAlukku vaTakku [i]ra[N]TA[g]ka-
21 N[N]ARRu iraNTAñcatira[m ni]la[m] n[A]lumA[vi]l vaTakka[T]aiy ni[la]m orumAvil m[e]RkkaTaiy nilam araimAvum Aka nilam orumA [|*] in-ni[la]m orumAvum ivaru-
22 kku viRRukkoLvatAna emmilli[c]aiñca vilaipporu[L] an[RA](A)Tu n_alk-kAcu [o]n[Ru] [|*] ikkAcu onRum AvaNakkaLiye kaiccellaRakkoNTu [vi]RRu vilaiyA-
23 vaNa[m] ceyi[tu] kuTut[t]om brahmate[yam] ciRupazuvUr sabhaiyom [|*] innilam oru[m]Avukkum ituve vilaiyolai AvatAkavum itu[ve]1620po-ru[m]AvaRu-
24 [ti]ppo[ruLci]lav[o]lai[y]AvatAkavu[m] ituva[l*]latu v[e]Ru 3-154-2>porumAva-RutipporuLccila[v]olai kATTakkaTavar allAtArAkavum [|*] ippaTi i-caiñ-
25 cu ikkAcu onRu[m koN]Tu innilam [o]rumAvum vilaikkaRa viRRu poru-LaRakkoNTom ciRupazuvUr sabhaiyom [|*] ivarkaL paNikka ip[pi]- ramANam ezutine-
26 n [ma]dhyastan1621 pa[zuvUru]TaiyAn A[yi]rattirunURRuvan muTikoNTAnen i-v[ai] ennezut[tu] [|*] ippaTik[ku c]An[ta]magka[la]ttu pAlAci[riya]n [ila]kkuvaNa[n_]
27 [kU]ttap[pa](n)nen ivai ennezuttu [|*] ip[pa]Tikku pazuvU[r*] ca[v]A[nti] nArANanen ivai ennezu[ta]tu [|*] itu cAnti palAciriyan1622viranA-rAya[Na]natu [|*] itu cA[vA]nti nArAyaNan mARan [|*]
28 yippaTi aRiven ivvUr vIracozaviNNaka(r)rAzvAr koyil tiru[v]ArA-ta[n]ai pa[N]Num nArAyaNan tiruvA[yi]kkulamuTaiyAnen [|*] [i]ppaTi aRiven
29 ivvUr karumAn1623 [|*] itu pa[nm]A[hE]zva[rara]kSai §


TRANSLATION.



(Line 17.) In the twentieth year (of the reign) of king Rājakēsarivarman, alias) the emperor of the three worlds, Śrī-Kulōttuṅga-Śōl6adēva, who etc.1624--we, the assembly of Śiṟupal6uvūr, a brahmadēya) in Kuṉṟa-kūṟṟam, (a subdivision) of Uttoṅgatoṅga-vaḷa-nāḍu, sold the following land at a price (settled by) the assembly to Śōl6akulasundaraṉ-Vichchādiri Āl6vār, the mother of Vi[ru]darājabhayaṁkara-Vāṇakō[va]raiyar.
(L. 19.) One fortieth (vēli) of land on the eastern side of the one twentieth (vēli) of land on the northern side of the four twentieths (vēli) of land of the second square of the first kaṇṇāṟu1625 to the north of the Rājēndra-Śōl6a) channel (and) to the east of the Pavitti-[ram]āṇikka road.
[page 3-155]
(L. 20.) And one fortieth (vēli) of land on the western side of the one twentieth (vēli) of land on the northern side of the four twentieths (vēli) of land (of) the second square of the second kaṇṇāṟu) to the east of this road (and) to the north of this channel.
(L. 21.) Altogether, one twentieth (vēli) of land. The price which we have to receive from her for this one twentieth (vēli) of land, (and) on which we have agreed, (is) one good kāśu current at the time.1626
(L. 22.) Having received this one kāśu in full into the hand••••••••••1627 we, the assembly of the brahmadēya) of Śiṟupal6uvūr, sold (the land) and made and gave a deed of sale. For this one twentieth (vēli) of land this alone shall be the record of sale, and this alone shall be the record of the final payment of the money,1628 and they (viz. the purchasers) shall not be bound to produce another record of the final payment of the money besides this.
(L. 24.) Having thus agreed, having received this one kāśu, and having sold this one twentieth (vēli) of land at the full price, we, the assembly of Śiṟupal6uvūr, have received the money in full.
(L. 25.) By their order, I, the Madhyastha1629 Pa[l6uvūr-U]ḍaiyāṉ Āyirattiru-nūṟṟuvaṉ Muḍikoṇḍāṉ, wrote this document (pramāṇa); this is my writing. I, Pālā-śiriyaṉ[Ila]kkuvaṇaṉ (Lakshmaṇa) [Kū]ttappaṉ of [Ś]ān[da]maṅgalam, (know) this; this is my writing. I, Śa[v]āndi Nārāṇaṉ (i.e. Nārāyaṇa) of Pal6uvū[r], (know) this; this is my writing. This (is the writing) of Śāndi Palāśiriyaṉ Vīranārāyaṇaṉ. This (is the writing of) Śā[vā]ndi Nārāyaṇaṉ Māṟaṉ. Thus do I know, Nārāyaṇaṉ Tiruvā[yi]kkulam-Uḍaiyāṉ,1630 who performs the worship of the temple of Vīra-Śōl6a-Viṇṇagar-Āl6vār in this village. Thus do I know, the blacksmith of this village. This (is placed under) the protection of all Māhēśvaras.


No. 72.--INSCRIPTION AT TIRUVIDAIMARUDUR.



This inscription (No. 132 of 1895) is engraved on the east wall of the second prākāra of the Mahāliṅgasvāmin temple at Tiruviḍaimarudūr1631 in the Kumbhakōṇam tāluka of the Tanjore district. This village is mentioned in Tiruñāṉasambandar's Dēvāram as Iḍai-marudu. The Sanskrit equivalent of this name is Madhyārjuna,1632 in which madhya corresponds to iḍai, 'the middle,' and arjuna to marudu, 'Terminalia alata.' In the subjoined inscription the village is called Tiruviḍaimarudil1633 and its temple Tiruviḍai-marud-Uḍaiyār (i.e). the lord of Tiruviḍaimarudu). It belonged to Tiraimūr-nāḍu, a subdivision of Ulaguyyakkoṇḍa-Śōl6a-vaḷanāḍu.1634 The inscription records a grant of 120 sheep for two lamps. The Pūjāris of the temple and the inhabitants of Tiruviḍai-marudil and Tiraimūr were appointed trustees of the grant. Tiraimūr I do not find on the[page 3-156] map; but, as its inhabitants seem to have had a share in the management of the temple at Tiruviḍaimarudūr, it was probably not far distant from the latter.
The date is the 172nd day of the 26th year of the reign of Kulōttuṅga I. The historical introduction agrees with that of the 20th year (No. 71 above), but adds that the king conquered the Kaliṅga-maṇḍalam (l. 4). Other inscriptions refer to a single queen, who is styled 'the mistress of the whole world,'1635 'the mistress of the whole earth,'1636 or 'the mistress of the world,'1637 and who is perhaps identical with Madhurāntakī, the daughter of Rājēndradēva.1638 In addition to this queen,1639 the subjoined inscription mentions three other queens, viz. Dīnachintāmaṇi, Ēl6iśai-Vallabhī,1640 and Tyāgavallī. Of the last of these the Kaliṅgattu-Paraṇi (x. verse 55) states that "she had the right to issue orders together with the orders of the Śeṉṉi (i.e. the Chōḷa king)."


TEXT.



1 --|| svasti SrI ||--pukaz [cU][z*]nta puNari akaz cUznta [pu]viyil ponkemi aLavum tan [n]emi naTappa vi[La]gku jayamakaLai iLag[c]opparuvattuccak-karakoTTattu vikkiramattozilARputumaNam puNarntu matuva[r]ai1641 ITTam [vayi]rAkarattu vAri a[yi]lmu[n_ai] ko[ntaLava]raicar ta[n] taLami[ri]ya vALuRai kazittu to[L] vali kATTi porppari naTA[t]ti1642kir[t]tiyai [ni]Rutti vaTaticai vAkai [cU]Ti[t]t[en_]Ricaittemaru[kamalappUmaka]L [po]tum[ai]yum p[o]n_ni[y]A[Tai] nan_nilappAvai tan_i[mai]yum [ta]vir-ttu1643pu[n_i]ta[R]tirumaNimakuTam urimaiyiRcUTi tan_naTi iraNTuntaTamuTiyAka-ttonnilaventar cU[Ti] mu[n_n_ai] manuvARu peruka kaliyARu va[Ru]ppa cegkol ticai-
2 t[o]Ruñcella ve[N]kuTai1644[i]runi[la]vi[L]AkammegkaNuntan_Atu tirunila-veNNil[A]ttica[za]vorutan_i meruviRpuli viLaiyATa1645vArkaTaRRivAntara-ttuppUpAlar tiRai viTutanta [kala]ñc[o][ri] ca[Lu]Ru1646 muRai niR[pa] vila-gkiya1647 piRkulappiRai pol [ni]Rpizaiyen_n_uñcolletirkkoTiRRallatu tan_ kai vil[l]etirkkoTA [vi]kkalan kal[la]kar1648 nag[ki]li tuTag[ki ma]- Na[lUr naTuvena tu]gkaTatti[r]ai [pu]katturatti vegkaNum1649 paT[Ta] vegkaLiRu[m] viTTa [ta]n [m]Anamug[kU]Riya1650viramugkiTappa eRin_a [ma]lai-kaLu[mu]tuku neLippa izin_ta netikaLuñkaza[n_Ru]TaintoTa vizunta kaTalkaLunta[lai]virittala[ma]ra-
3 kkuTa[ti]caittan_n_A[Lu]kantu tAn_untA[n]aiyum pa[n_]n_ALiTTa palapala mu[tu]- ku[m] payatte[ri1651 m]ARiya jayapperuna[ti]ruvum pa[zi]yu[ka]n[tu] kuTutta

5 ppuya[t]talagkalum po[l1660vi]ramum tiyAka[mu]m viLag[ka] pAr tozacciva-niTattumai(y)y[e]natti[n_a]cintAmaNi1661 puvan_amuzutuTaiy[A]Lirup[pa] avaLuTan_ kagkai1662viRRirunten_a [mag][k*]aiyar tilatam ezicaiva[l]lapi ezulaka[mu]- TaiyAL vAzi amar[n_]tinitiruppa Uziya[m]1663 tirumAlAcattu piriyA[t]e-nta1664 tirumakaL tikazenattiyAka[val]litta[m] ulakuTaiyA[Li]ruppa mAvi[n_i]l [pu]vanamuzutu[T]aiyALoTum 3-157-11>viR[Riru]ntaruLiya kovirAjakesari[panma]rAn_a cakkiravattikaL SrIkulottugkac[o]zatevarkku yA[N]Tu 26 Avatu [ka]l veTTum pa[Ti y]ANTu 26 Ava[tu n]AL 172n_Al ulakuyya[k]-

7 kANi p[A]ratAyan_ [eTu]ttapAtam i[n_]puRRiruntAnAn_a p[o]Rkoyil nampi-[k]kum [kara]NattA[n_uk]ku[m] SrI[mu]kam pirasAtañceytaruLi varatatalai mel [k]oNTu pirasAtappaTTu paT[TiyUru]T[ai]yAn_ nampan_ maturAntakatevanAn_a kulottugkacoza[vi]RainATTu 3-157-15>[mu]ventaveLAn_ 3-157-16>{??vaitta [ti]runontA-vi[Lak]ku iraNTin_ukku vaitta ATu 120 [|*] [iv]vATu nUR[Riru]patum ko[N]Tu ekanAyakanAl [nitta]m u[ri]y ney[ya]TTuvatA[ka]kk[o]NTa ma[n_]RATi tAmo[tira]n_ veN[k]ATan_um tevan_ iTagk[o]NTAn_um [ma]ru[ta]n_ t[e]van_u[m] paTTa[n_ p]erRAn_um inta ATu
[page 3-158]
8 nURRirupa[tu]gk[o][N]Tu nittam ekanA[ya]kanAl uriy ney zantirAtit[ta]val in_ney ta[N]Ti i[tti]runontAviLakku iraNTum e[ri]ppikka kaTavomA-n_om tevar kan[mi]kaLuntiraimur1668 sabhaiyArum tiruviTaimarutil na[ka]ra-ttArum tiraimur 3-158-1> [U]rAru[m] [||*] i[vai SrI]koyil [ka]Nakku ko-RRa[magka]lamuTaiyAn_ arumozi poRkAri ezuttu [||*] itu panmAhE-zvara[rakS]ai || §


TRANSLATION.



(Line 4.)1669 (He) was pleased to seize the Kaliṅga-maṇḍalam, whose rivers were checked (by dams), and was pleased to take his seat (on the throne) with the mistress of the whole world who remained (his) chief consort,1670 while (his) valour and liberality shone like (his) necklace acquired in warfare and (like) the flower-garland on (his) royal shoulders; while (all men on) earth worshipped (him); while the mistress of the whole world, Dīnachintā-maṇi, was present, as Umā near Śiva; while the mistress of the seven worlds, Ēl6iśai-Vallabhī,--may she prosper !--the ornament of women, was calmly and joyfully seated, as Gaṅgā takes her seat with her (viz. Umā); (and) while his (i.e. the king's favourite) mistress of the world, Tyāgavallī, possessing the splendour of Lakshmī who is inseparably clinging1671 to the bosom of Tirumāl (Vishṇu) to the end of the world, was present.
(L. 5.) In the 26th year (of the reign) of this king Rājakēsarivarman, alias the emperor Śrī-Kulōttuṅga-Śōl6adēva,--the Pañchāchārya) (who wears) a silk garment (in honour of) the feet of the god1672 Tiruviḍaimarud-Uḍaiyār, and the Pūjāris of the god were pleased to send a letter (śrīmugam) to the members of the assembly of Tiraimūr, to the citizens of Tiruviḍaimarudil, to the villagers of Tiraimūr, to the temple-manager Vaḍa-Śāttamaṅgalam-Uḍaiyāṉ Kūttaṉ1673 Sōmadēvaṉ, alias Kaṉṉa[gi]darapāṇi-Mūvēndavēḷāṉ, to the overseer of the Śrī-Māhēśvaras, [Eḍu]ttapādam1674 I[ṉ]buṟṟi-rundāṉ, alias Poṟkōyil-Nambi,1675 of the Bhāradvāja (gōtra), and to the accountant--to the effect that it should be engraved on stone1676 that, on the 172nd day of the 26th year (of the king's reign), Paṭṭiyūr-Uḍaiyāṉ Nambaṉ Madurāntakadēvaṉ, alias Kulōttuṅga-Śōl6a-[Vi]ṟaināṭṭu Mūvēndavēḷāṉ, had given a perpetual lamp1677 to (the temple of) Tiruviḍaimarud-Uḍaiyār, the lord of Tiraimūr-nāḍu, (a subdivision) of Ulaguy-ya[k2k]oṇḍa-Śōl6a-vaḷanāḍu.
(L. 7.) When (this letter) arrived, (the addressees) placed (it) on (their) heads and felt honoured. Paṭṭiyūr-Uḍaiyāṉ Nambaṉ Madurāntakadēvaṉ, alias Kulōttuṅga-Śōl6a-[Vi]ṟaināṭṭu Mūvēndavēḷāṉ, had assigned 120 sheep for the two perpetual lamps given (by him), in order to supply one uri) of ghee per day by the E4kanāyakaṉ (measure). These one hundred and twenty sheep were taken over by Maṉṟāḍi Tāmōdiraṉ (Dāmōdara)[page 3-159] Veṇgāḍaṉ,1678 Dēvaṉ Iḍaṅgoṇḍāṉ, Marudaṉ1679 Dēvaṉ and Paṭṭaṉ Peṟṟāṉ. We, the Pūjāris of the god, the members of the assembly of Tiraimūr, the citizens of Tiruviḍaimarudil, and the villagers of Tiraimūr, shall be bound to levy, as long as the moon and the sun exist, this one uri of ghee per day by the E4kanāyakaṉ (measure) from (the recipients of) these one hundred and twenty sheep and to keep these two perpetual lamps burning.
(L. 8.) This (is) the writing of the accountant of the temple, Koṟṟamaṅgalam-Uḍaiyāṉ Arumol6i Poṟkāri. This (is placed under) the protection of all Māhēśvaras.


No. 73.--INSCRIPTION AT CHOLAPURAM.



The inscriptions of Kulōttuṅga I. inform us that he conquered and colonized Kōṭṭāṟu.1680 This ancient town now belongs to the Travancore State and is situated about 10 miles north of Cape Comorin and near the British Post Office. "Nagercoil." A temple named Chōḷēśvara is now included in a quarter of Nagercoil which bears the name Chōḷapuram, while according to the subjoined inscription it belonged to Kōṭṭāṟu itself. The inscription (No. 31 of 1896) is engraved on the north, west and south walls of the first prākāra of this temple.
The date is the 180th day of the [30]th year of the reign of Kulōttuṅga I. The historical introduction agrees on the whole with that of No. 72. But, among the queens, Dīnachintāmaṇi is omitted and Tyāgavallī mentioned in the first place. Hence it may be concluded that Dīnachintāmaṇi died between the 26th and 30th years of the king's reign.1681
The inscription records that Kulōttuṅga I. himself, while staying in his palace at Kāñchipuram, granted to the temple the village of Āndāyakkuḍi, which received the new name Rājēndra-Śōl6a-nallūr. The temple itself, we are told, was built by one of the king's officers and named Rājēndra-Śōl6a-Īśvara. Both this name and the new name of the village granted must have been chosen with reference either to Rājēndra-Chōḷa II.,1682 the name which Kulōttuṅga I. bore during the first few years of his reign, or to Rājēndra-Chōḷa I., the name of his maternal grandfather. Kōṭṭāṟu had the surname Mummuḍi-Śōl6a-nallūr1683 and belonged to Nāñji-nāḍu,1684 a subdivision of Uttama-Śōl6a-vaḷanāḍu, a district of Rājarāja-Pāṇḍi-nāḍu.1685
The inscription is incomplete at the end, and lines 5 and 6 are so much damaged that they cannot be published. They contain a detailed description of the boundaries of the village granted and mention the villages of Al6agiya-Pāṇḍiyapuram (ll. 4 and 6), Śivīndiram,1686 Tarumapuram, Irāśak[ka]maṅgalam (l. 5), Śillūr, and the temple of Maṇivaṇ-ṇīśvara (l. 6).
[page 3-160]

TEXT.



1 svasti SrI [||*] puka[z] cUznta puNari akaz cU[z]nta puviyiRa[p]po[n_]n_e-miyaLavu[nta]n_n_[e]mi naTappa viLa[g]ku [ja]yamakaLai iLagkopparuvattuccak-karakoTTattu vi[k]ki[ra]mattozilA[Rpu]tumaNam puNarntu16871688matuva[r]ai[yI]- TTam [va]yirAkarattu [v]Ari ayilmu[n_ai*]kkunta[Lava]raica[r] ta[n ta]Lamiri1689 . •••••••• [niRutti] vaTa[ti]cai vAkai [cU]Ti[t]te[n_]Ricai[t-t]emarukamalappUmakaL1690pantumai[yu]m pon_n_iyATai nan_n_i[lappA]v[ai tan_i-m]aiyun[ta]viru1691 van[tu1692pun_ita]R[ti]rumaNi[maku]Ta[m] urimaiyiRcUTi[ttan_]n_a-Ti[yi]raNTuntaTamuTiyAkattonnilav[Enta]r [cUTa] mu[n_]n_ai [man_uvARu pe]ru-kakkali[y]ARu [vaRuppac]cegkol ticai[t][o]Ru[ñc]ella [v]eNkuTai i[runila]vaLA[ka]m1693[v]eNkaNuntan_Atu tiru[niza]l[A] veN[Ni]lA[t]tikaza orutan_i meruviR[pu]li viLaiyATa vA[rka]TaR[RI]pA[n]tarat[tu]ppUpar [ti]Rai [vi]Tu[tanta kalañ]co[ri kaLi]Ru [mu{??}]1694••••• [{??}gkiya] ten_[n_avan_ karunta]lai [pa]ru[ntalaittiTattan_] p[on_n_a]ka[r puRattiTaikki]Tappa [in_a-n_A]L [pi]R[kula]p[piRai p]ol1695niRpi[z]aiy[o]m[en_uñ]col[l]e[ti]r k[o]TiRRalla[tu tan_] kai villetir ko[T]A veLpula[t]taracu aLat-tiyiliT[Ta kaLiRRaLa]t[tI]TTa[mu]m1696 paT[Ta v]e[m]pa[riyum vi]T[Ta tan_ mAn_amugkURin_a]1697vi[ramu]gkiTappa eRin_a malai[kaLumutuku] ne[Li]ppa [i]- zinta [na]ti[ka]LuñcUzan_RuTainto-1698
2 Ta vizunta kaTalkaLu[n]talaivirittalamarakkuTatic[ai]ttan_n_ALukanta tA[n_u]n[t]An_ai-yum pan_n_ALiTTa [pa]la[pa]la mu[tuku]m paya[t]te[ti]r m[ARi]ya [ja]yapperu-[n]tiruvum pa[zi]yukantu kuTut[ta]1699pukazuñcelviyum vALAro[N]kaN ma[Ta]ntaiyariTTa[mum]1700 miLAtu [ku]Tutta veg[ka]ri niraiyugkagkamaNTalamu-[g]kogkaNatecamum [p]ANiyi[ra]NTum oruvi[c]ai[k]kaikkoN[TIN*]Tiya pu[ka]LoTu1701 pANTimaNTalamugkoLLat[ti]ruvuLLat[ta]Taittu veLLavarupari-t[ta]ragka[mum p]oru[ka]rikkalag[ka]Luntantira[v]Ari[yumu]TaittA[y va]ntu va-TakaTal ten_kaTal [paTa]rva[tu] pola[tta]n_ p[e]ru[ñ]ce[n_ai] evippañca-varai[var] p[o]ru[ta] m[o][y]ka[Lat]tañci veru neLitt[o]Ti [a]- raN[en_appu]kka kATaRa[t]tuTai[ttu nATTaTipaTut]tu maRRa[var]tam[mai] van_acara[r] tiriyum [p]occ[ai] veñcu[ra]m[e]RRikkoRRavijaiyastampam 1702[a]tticaitoRu[m] niRutta mut[ti]n_ cilA[pa]mum muttamiT[pati]yi[n_um]1703 ma•••••• [pa]Tum maiy[ya]cc[aiyyamug]ka[n_]n_i[yu]gk[ai]k[k]o[N-TaruLitten_n_A]T[Talai]1704 kATTi[y] kaTal[malainaT]TuLan_a1705 cAveRellA[n]- ta[n_i] vi[cu]mpeRa m[Av]eRiya [ta]n_1706varutan_i[ttalai]varai[k]kuRukalar kulai-yaka[k]oTTARuTpaTa n[e]Ri[t]oRunilaika[Li]TTaru[Li]ttiRal koLAramu[nti-
[page 3-161] ru]ppuyatta[la]gkaLu[m]1707 pol1708viramun[tiy]Akamu[m] vi[La]gkappAr toza-cciva[n_i]Tat[tu]-
3 [mai*]yen_at[ti]yAkavalli ava[n_i]muzutuTaiyALiruppa avan_uTan_ kagkai1709viR-Rirunten_a [ma]gkaiyar tilata[m] ezicaivalla[pi] e[zula]kuTai[y]A[L v]A-ziya malarn[ti]n_itiruppa Uziyu[m] avan_imuzu[tu]TaiyALoTum vIrasiMhAsan_a-ttu [vI*]RRiru[n]taruLin_a [k]ovirAjakecari[panma]rAn_a cakkaravarttikaL [SrI]ku-lo[t]tug[ka]co[za]t[e]var k[A]ñcipu[rat]tu[k]k[oyilin_uL]L[A]l a[T-Ta]tatu ve[Lm]elaimaNTa[pa]m rAjentiracoza[n_i]l coTTai[yi]l e[zu]- n[ta]ru[Liyi]runtu rAjarAjapp[A]N[Ti]nATTu uttama[c]oza[va]Lan[AT]Tu [n]A-ñcinATTukk[oTT]ARA[n_a mu]mmuTico[za]nal[lU]ril [c]oza[ma]NTalattu maNNinATTu muzaiyUruTaiyAn_ araiyan_ maturAntakan_An_a kulottug[ka]co-zakkeraLarA[ja]n_ eTuppitta irAcentiracozaIzvaramuTaiya mahA[dEvar]- kku innATTu AntAyakku[Tik]ku kANikka[Tan_ kAcu ezupat]ton_pa[tukku]ma n[e]llu mun_n_URRirupattu nARkalattuk[ku]m [i]rAjEntracozatevaRku eRin_avANTu ezAvatu cela[vi]n_ paTi iRai kaTTin_a mATai nARpatta-[ñ]caraiye mummAvaraiyum yAN[Tu 30]tAvatu mutal itteva[R]ku1710veN-Tu[niva]ntagkaLukku iRuppatAka ivvU-
4 r mun_ [pi]yar tavirntu i[r]AjEntracozana[l]lUren_n_um piyarAl Urkkaza-ñcu kumarakkaccANamu[mI]n_pATTamu[m*] taRiyi[Rai ta]TT[Ar]ppATTamu[m]A-TaikkU[liyunta]ca[vanta]gk[A]laLa[vu]kU[li]yum uLLiTTa pATTagka[Lum] an-tarAyamum cilaku[Ti]maiyum u[TpaTa] yANTu muppa[t]Avatu mutal teva-tA[n_a]iRai[yi]liyAka variyili[Ta]t[ti]ruvAy mo[zi]ntaru[Li]n_Aren_Ru tiru-[ma]nti[ra]volai keraLAntakappallavaraya[n_] ezuttin_Al pukunta ti[ru]vAy[k]- kezvi[p]pa[Ti pu]ra[vari]tiNaikkaLanAyakam arumo[zi]tevava[La]nATTu nAkan_- kuTai[y]An_ pañcaneti tirukkaNNapuramuTaiyAn_um mullUr kizavan_ veLAn_ kumaran_An_a kuvalaiyacuntaramuventaveLAn_um1711 puravariti[Nai]kka[La]ttu mukaveT[Ti i]rAcacun[ta]ravaLanATTu ampa[r]nATTu aNTakkuTaiyAn_ n[A*]rAyaNan_ [ti]- ruc[ci]RRam[pala]muTai[yA]n_u[m] ku. [lUruTaiy]A[n_] a[r]aiyan_ kuTit[A]g-[kiy]A[n_a i]r[A]jan[A*]rAya[NamU]ve[ntaveLAn_um iru]n[tu y]A[NTu] •••• vatu nAL nURReNpatin_Al tevatAn_a iRai[yili]yAka va[riyili]- TTatu [|*] ivvUr k[o]n_ irAcarA[can_] A[n_a] k[o]lottugka[c]o-za[n]Añ[ci]nATu[T]ai[yA][n_*] ivvUrkku[c]camai[n]tu1712 perunAn_kellai [aRaiolai] [|*] cey[ta] aR[ai]olaippa[Ti] i[ta]Rku kIzpA[Rke]llai [a]za-[ki]yapA[NTiya]purattukku-
5 [pp]on_a [va]zik[ku] meRku[m]••••••••


TRANSLATION.



[The historical introduction is the same as in No. 69, with the following differences.]
(Line 12 f. of No. 69.) For "Vikkalaṉ" No. 73 substitutes "Vēḷpulattaraśu."1713
(L. 13 f. of No. 69.) "At Aḷatti there were lying low herds of elephants abandoned (by him), the dead (bodies of his) fiery horses, his lost pride and (his) boasted valour."
[page 3-162]
(L. 16 of No. 69.) "(The Chōḷa king) seized simultaneously the two countries (called) Gaṅga-maṇḍalam and Koṅgaṇa-dēśam,1714 troops of furious elephants," &c.
[Instead of the passage in line 4 f. of No. 72, which was translated on page 158 above, No. 73 reads:] "(He) was pleased to take his seat on the throne of heroes for life-time with the mistress of the whole earth, while (his) valour and liberality shone like (his) necklace acquired in warfare and (like) the flower-garland on (his) royal shoulders; while (all men on) earth worshipped (him); while the mistress of the whole earth, Tyāgavallī, was present, as Umā near Śiva; (and) while the mistress of the seven worlds, Ēl6iśai-Vallabhī,--may she prosper !--the ornament of women, was pleasantly and joyfully seated, as Gaṅgā takes her seat with him (viz. Śiva)."
(L. 3.) While this king Rājakēsarivarman, alias the emperor Śrī-Kulōttuṅga-Śōl6adēva, was graciously seated on the śoṭṭai (?) in the white (?) maṇḍapa (called after) Rājēndra-Śōl6aṉ in the west of the octangular (court ?) within the royal palace at Kāñchi-puram,1715 he was pleased to order as follows:--"To (the god) Mahādēva (of the temple) of Rājēndra-Śōl6a-Īśvara, which Araiyaṉ Madurāntakaṉ, alias Kulōttuṅga-Śōl6a-Kēraḷarājaṉ, the lord of Mul6aiyūr in Maṇṇi-nāḍu,1716 (a district) of Śōl6a-maṇḍalam, had caused to be built at Kōṭṭāṟu, alias) Mummuḍi-Śōl6a-nallūr, in Nāñji-nāḍu, (a subdivision) of Uttama-Śōl6a-vaḷanāḍu, (a district) of Rājarāja-Pāṇḍi-nāḍu, shall be paid, for the expenses required by this god, from the [30]th year (of my reign) forty-five and a half, three twentieths and one fortieth māḍai1717 by (the village of) Āndāyakkuḍi in the same nāḍu). According to (the settlement of) payments (that had taken place) in the seventh year after the accession of Rājēndra-Śōl6adēva,1718 (this) tax was paid instead of the (original) land-tax of seventy-nine kāśu and three hundred and twenty-four kalam of paddy. The previous name of this village having been cancelled and the name of Rājēndra-Śōl6a-nallūr (having been substituted), let it be entered in the revenue-register (vari)1719 as a tax-free dēva-dāna from the thirtieth year (of my reign), including rents, internal revenue,1720 and small rights, such as ūr-kal6añju, kumara-kachchāṇam, the fishing-rent,1721 the tax on looms,1722 the rent of the goldsmiths,1723 māḍai-kūli, daśavandam1724 and kāl-aḷavu-kūli."
(L. 4.) In accordance with this royal order, received with the signature of the royal secretary, Kēraḷāntaka-Pallavarayaṉ, it was entered in the revenue-register as a tax-free dēvadāna on the one-hundred-and-eightieth day of the••••• th year (of the king's reign) in the presence of the Puravaritiṇaikkaḷa-nāyagam1725 Pañchanedi Tirukkaṇṇapuram-Uḍaiyāṉ, the lord of Nāgaṉgu[ḍi] in Arumol6idēva-vaḷanāḍu;[page 3-163] Vēḷāṉ Kumaraṉ, alias Kuvalayasundara-Mūvēndavēḷāṉ, the headman of Mullūr; the Puravaritiṇaikkaḷattu-Mugaveṭṭi1726 N[ā]rāyaṇaṉ Tiruchchiṟṟambalam-Uḍaiyāṉ, the lord of Aṇḍakku[ḍi] in Ambar-nāḍu, (a subdivision) of Rājasundara-vaḷanāḍu; and Araiyaṉ Kuḍitāṅgi, alias Rājan[ā]rāyaṇa-Mūvēndavēḷāṉ, the lord of Ku•• [lūr]. The chief (kōṉ) of this village, Rājarājaṉ, alias Kulōttuṅga-Śōl6a-Nāñjināḍ-Uḍaiyā[ṉ], (drew up) a document specifying1727 the four great boundaries of this village. According to the document drawn up (by him), the eastern boundary of this (village is) to the west of the road leading to Al6agiya-Pāṇḍiyapuram••••• •••••

No. 74.--INSCRIPTION IN THE PANDAVA-PERUMAL TEMPLE.



This inscription (No. 18 of 1893) is engraved on the south wall of the Pāṇḍava-Perumāḷ temple at Conjeeveram. As in No. 68 above, the name of the temple is given as Tiruppāḍagam (l. 3).
The date is the 39th year of the reign of Kulōttuṅga I. But the historical introduc-tion agrees almost literally with an inscription of the 5th year in the same temple (No. 68 above), while the intervening inscriptions (Nos. 69 to 73, 78, and Vol. II. No. 58) contain much additional matter.
The inscription records that a merchant of Kāñchipuram paid two kal6añju and two mañjāḍi of gold to the Pūjāris of the temple, who pledged themselves to have the god supplied daily with two nāl6i of curds.


TEXT.



1 svasti SrI [||*] pukaz cU[z*]nta puNari akaz cUznta puviyil ponnEmiyaLavu[nta]- nnEmi na[T]Atti viLa[g]ku jayamakaL iLagko paruvattu cakkarakoTTattu vikkiramattozilAl putumaNam puNarnta1728 va[n_]ka[Li*]RRiTTa[m*]1729 vaiyi-rAkarattu v[A*]ri1730aiyilmunaikkontaLavarai[ca]r tantanamiri[ya] vALu[R]ai kazittu toL vali kATTi porppari naTAtti [kI]rtti[y]ai niRutti vaTatic[ai] vAkai cUTi tenticai temaru[ka]mala[ppU]maka[L1731pu]tu[m]aiyum p[o]nniyATai(yum) [nanni]lappAvaiyu[nta]nimaiyu[nta]vi[r*]ttu17321733[pu]nitarutiru-maNimakuTam [mu]Raimaiyil cUTi tannaTi iraNTum taTamuTiyAka
2 [t]on[nila]ventar cUTa ponni matuvARu [p]e[ru]ka ka[li]yARu vaRappa ce-gko[l ti]cait[o]Ruñ[c]ella [v]eNkuTai iru[ni]lava[L]AkamegkaNu- nta[n]Atu tirunilaveNNi[l]Atti[ka]za orutani meruvil puli viLaiyATa Az-[ka]Tal1734tivAntarattu pUvar tiRai viTutta kala[n_] co[ri*] kaLuRu1735 muRai niRpa vi[La]gkiya tennavanaruntalai paruntalai[ttu] ki[Ta]ppa [na]n_maNiyAramunti ruppu[ya]ttala[g]kalum1736 tantu1737 vIramum tiyAkamum viLagka pArmicai mevalar vaNagka [vI]rasiMhAsanattu avanimuzutuTaiyALoTum1738viRRiru-
3 ntaruLiya ko[vi]rAjakesaripanmarAna uTaiyAr SrIkulottugkacozatevarkku [y]ANTu muppatton_[pa]tAvatu jayagk[o]NTacozamaN[Ta*]lattu eyirk-koTTattu1739 nakarag[k]Añcipurattu tiruppATakattAzvAnaittiruvArAtan[ai]
[page 3-164] paNNum [bh]AradvAci1740 ninRanArAyaNapaTTanenum dU[da]kari tiruvara[g]kam[A]- NipaTTane[nu]m cilA[le*]k[ai] pa[N*]NikkuTutta paricAvatu [|*] inna- ka[ra]ttu1741rAjASriyapp[e]runtEruvil irukku[m] vANiyan_ toTTagkizA-nAtan coman [pa]kkal [n]Agka[L] kaikkoN[Ta] matu[r]AntakamATai-
4 yoTokkum pon_ kuTiñaikkal niRai irukazañce i[ra]NTu mañcA-Tikkum p[o]licaiyAl ivvAz[vA*]nukku nittap[pa]Tikku [ni]nRAnnAl1742 [i]runAzi taiyi[ra]mutu ce[y]kai[k*]ku celuttakka[Ta]vomAkavumATaTo-mAkila celuttuvAr pakkalippon_ [ku]Tukka kaTavomAkavum [|*] ikkoyil kANi tavi[r*]ntu p[o]killipp[o]n_ oTu[kki]p[p]okak[ka]TavomAnom ivvi[ru]v[o]m ||--


TRANSLATION.



(Line 3.) In the thirty-ninth year (of the reign) of king Rājakēsarivarman, alias the lord Śrī-Kulōttuṅga-Śōl6adēva, who etc.1743--the following writing on stone was made and given by me, Niṉṟanārāyaṇa-Bhaṭṭaṉ of the Bhāradvāja (gōtra) and by me, Dū[da]kari1744 Tiruvaraṅgamāṇi-Bhaṭṭaṉ, who are performing the worship in the temple of Tiruppāḍagatt-Āl6vāṉ at Kāñchipuram, a city in Eyiṟkōṭṭam,1745 (a district) of Jayaṅgoṇḍa-Śōl6a-maṇḍalam. From Tōṭṭaṅgil6ānādaṉ Sōmaṉ, a mer-chant who resides in the great street of Rājāśraya1746 in this city, we have received two kal6añju and two mañjāḍi of gold, weighed by the standard of the city (kuḍiñai-kal) (and) equal (in fineness) to the Madurāntaka-māḍai.1747
(L. 4.) Out of the interest from (this) we shall be bound to pay for supplying daily to this god two nāl6i of curds by the Niṉṟāṉ (? measure). If we are not able (to pay it), we shall be bound to make over this gold to those who will pay (it). If (our) right (to serve) in this temple should cease, we two shall be bound to refund this money before leaving.


No. 75.--INSCRIPTION AT TIRUKKALUKKUNRAM.



This inscription (No. 179 of 1894) is engraved on the south wall of the second prākāra of the Vēdagirīśvara temple at Tirukkal6ukkuṉṟam.1748 It has been published before in a tentative manner by Mr. V. Kanakasabhai Pillai in the Indian Antiquary, Vol. XXI. p. 281 ff.1749 The date is the 42nd year of the reign of Kulōttuṅga I. (l. 11).
The inscription records that an inhabitant of Rājarājapuram (l. 17) made over
10 kāśu (l. 14) to the temple authorities, who purchased for this sum from the villagers of Vāṉavaṉmahādēvi-chaturvēdimaṅgalam (l. 11) some land for maintaining the
[page 3-165] Maṭha of Naminandi-Aḍigaḷ at Tirukkal6ukkuṉṟam (l. 14). As stated by Mr. Kanaka-sabhai,1750 the person after whom this Maṭha was named is one of the sixty-three devotees of Śiva, whose lives are described in the Periyapurāṇam.
Vāṉavaṉmahādēvi-chaturvēdimaṅgalam belonged to Kumil6i-nāḍu, a subdivision of the district of Āmūr-kōṭṭam (l. 11). The land purchased was situated in Kīraippākkam, a hamlet in the west of that village (l. 12), and was bounded in the east by Uroḍagam, in the south by Tāl6aivēḍu, in the west by Uragambākkam, and in the north by Taṇḍuṟai (l. 13). Kiraippākkam is the modern Kīrappākkam1751 in the Chingleput tāluka. East of it the map shows Oragaḍam (No. 228), south of it Tāl6ambēḍu (No. 266), and north of it Taṇḍaṟai (No. 233). The nāḍu to which these villages belonged is named after Kumil6i1752 in the same tāluka. The district of Āmūr-kōṭṭam owes its name to the village of Āmūr1753 near Māmallapuram,1754 which belonged to the subdivision Āmūr-nāḍu.1755 From the Koṇḍyāta grant of Veṅkaṭa II.1756 it appears that there was another district which also bore the name of Āmūr-kōṭṭam, but which was named after the town of Āmūr or Āmbūr in the Vēlūr tāluka of the North Arcot district.1757


TEXT.



1 svasti SrI [||*] [pu]kaz cU[z*]nta puNari akaz cUznta puviyil pon_nemi a[La]vuntan_ [n]emi naTappa vi[La]gku jayamakaLiLagkoppa[ruva]ttuccakkarako-TTattu vikki[ra]mattozilAl putumaNam puNa[r*]ntu1758ma[tu]varaiyITTam vayirAkarattu vAri ayilmu••••••••

3 n_n_aTiyiraNTuntaTamuTiyAkatton_n_ilaventar cUTa mun_n_ai manuvARu p[e]rukak-kali[yA]Ru [va]Ru[ppa]ccegkol ticait[o]Ruñcella veNkuTaiyirunila-vi[LA]kamm[e]gkaNuntan_Atu1762 [ti]runilaveNNilAtti(lAtti)kaza orutan_i m[e]- ruviRpuli vi[Lai]••••••••
4 vAntarattu pUpAlar tiRai viTuta[nta] kalañcori kaLi[Ru] muRai niRpa vilagkiya ten_n_a[va]n_ ka[ru]nta [lai]ppa[ru]ntalaittiTa tan_ pon_n_akar puRattiTaikkiTappa in_n_A[L] piRkulappiRai pol niRpizai en_n_u[m] colletir koTiR-Rallatu tan_ kai villetir koTA lezakulattara1763••••••••
5 TamuTTa[Ta] lezpa[riyu]m keTTa tan_ m[A]n_amum [kU]Rin_a vIramugkiTappa eRin_a malaikaLumutuku neLippa izinta n_atikaLuñcuzan_[Ru]TaintOTa
[page 3-166] vizunta kaTa[l]kaLuntalaivirittalamarakkuTaticaikkATu [u]kanta tAn_untAtaiyum pan_- n_ALiTTa palapala mu[tu*]kum [paya]tteti1764••••••••
6 peruntiruvum paziyukantu kuTutta pukazin_ celviyum vALAroN[ka]N maTa- nt[ai*]yarITTamumILAtu kuTutta vegkari niraiyugkagkamaNTalamuñcigkaName-n_n_um pANiyiraNTum o[ruvi]cai kaik[k]oNTINTiya pukazoTu pANTi-maNTala1765••••••••
7 LLattaT[ai]ttu vezparittalagkaLum1766 p[o]ruparittalagkaLunta[ntiravA]riyumuTait-tAyppara[ntu] vaTaticai1767 ten_kaTal pAy[va]tu polattan_ peruñcen_ai-yaiyevippañcavaraivarum poruta (poruta) p[o]rkkaLattañci veru ne-LittoTi araNen_ap1768••••••••

12 nATTu ulakaLantacozapuramAn_a cempiyantirukkazukkun_Rattu uTaiyAr tirukkazu-kkun_RamuTaiyamahAdEvar koyilil A[tid]Asa[r caNTezvara]dEvaRkku nA-gka[L] maTappuRamAka vi[R]RukkuTutta nilamAvatu [|*] egkaLur1778 melpiTAkai [kI]raippAkkam kATu koLA••••••••
13 Tu veTTikkaTTai paRittuttiru[t]tikkoLvatAkakkuTutta nilattukku1779kizpArkke-llaiyuroTaca[t]tellaiyuRavum tenpARkellai tAzaiveTTellaiyuRavum meR-pArkkellai u[ra]kamp[A][kka*]ttellai [u]Ravum [vaTap]ARkellai [ta]NTuRai ellai uRa[vu]m [|*] nA••••••••
14 [vu] paTTa nIr[ni]lamu[m] puñcainilamumen_o[k]kin_a maramug[kI]Nokkakin_a1780 kiNa-Rum ivvUr maTaiviLAkattirukkum naminanti a[Ti]kaL maTattukku maTa[p]puRa-
[page 3-167] mAka nA[g]kaLiRai izi[c]ci viRRukkuTuttu vilai[yAkka1781 n]Agka[L] kaik-koN[Ta a]n_RATu na[R]kAcu pattugkai••••••••
15 Ra viRRu poruLa[Ra]kkoNTu vilaiyAva[Na]ñceytu kuTuttom ma[h]A[sa]- bh[ai]yom [|*] in_n_ilattukku vanta ci[l]vari peruva[ri] maRRu ep-p[e]rppaTTatum nAgkaL[e] iRukka kaTavomAka sa[m]mati[tti]R[ai i]zicci viRRukkuTuttom [|*] sabh[ai](ka)[kku] camainta [kArA]m[pi]ccETTu [sarvv]Adi- ttan_ paNiyAl••••••••
16 [paT]Tan_uma[za]ppirAR[ku]mArasAmikkirama[vi]ttan_um1782u[Ru]ppuTTuraruLALapaTTa-[n_u]m pacumpuRattu SrIragkanAtapaTTan_u[m]1783 u[Ru]ppuTiTur1784 ca[gka]ranArAyaNapaT-Tan_um kura[va][c*]erittillai[kkU]tta[ka]kkikiramavittan_u[m]1785 ki[r]AñcittoNa-cUrakkiramavittan_um ivvan_aiv[o]m [candrar]A[ti]t••••••••
17 [le]kai paNNikkuTuttomahAsa[bh]aiy[o]m [|*] ippaTikku ivai vAn_ava-n_mahAdEvi uTaiyAn_ ce[l]van_ kuzaiñAn_ ezuttu ||--ittanma[m*] ceytAn eyiRkoTTattu rAjarAjapurattu tevantainAtan_ aruLALa[n]An_a kulottugkacozamApotiyarAya[Ran_]1786 ||--i[t*]ta[ru]ma••••••• •••


TRANSLATION.



(Line 11.) In the forty-second year (of the reign) of•••••••••• the emperor Śrī-Kulōttuṅga-Śōl6adēva, who etc.1787--we, the great assembly of Vāṉavaṉ-mahādēvi-chaturvēdimaṅgalam in Kumil6i-nāḍu, (a subdivision) of Āmūr-kōṭṭam, (a district) of Jayaṅgoṇḍa-Śōl6a-maṇḍalam, (drew up) a written deed of sale of land. We sold the following land, for maintaining1788 a Maṭha, to Ādidāsa [Chaṇḍēśvara]dēva1789 in the temple of Tirukkal6ukkuṉṟam-uḍaiya-Mahādēvar, the lord of Ulagaḷanda-Śōl6apuram, alias Śembiyaṉ-Tirukkal6ukkuṉṟam,1790 in [Kaḷattūr]-nāḍu, (a sub-division) of Kaḷattūr-[kōṭṭam].
(L. 12.) The land sold (at) [Kī]raippākkam, a western hamlet of our village, has to be reclaimed by cutting down•••••••••• the jungle and removing the stumps.
(L. 13.) The eastern boundary of (this land) adjoins the boundary of Uroḍagam; the southern boundary adjoins the boundary of Tāl6aivēḍu; the western boundary adjoins the boundary of U[ra]gamb[ākka]m; and the northern boundary adjoins the boundary of [Ta]ṇḍuṟai.
(L. 14.) Having freed from taxes the wet land and the dry land, the trees above and the wells below, [enclosed within these four boundaries], and sold (it) for maintaining the Maṭha of Naminandi-Aḍigaḷ, which is situated in the Maḍaiviḷāgam1791 of this village, we received as price ten good kāśu current at the time.1792
[page 3-168]
(L. 15.) Having sold•••••••••• and having received the money in full, we, the great assembly, made and gave a deed of sale. Having agreed that we alone should be bound to pay the small taxes, the big taxes,1793 and any other (tax) due on this land, we sold (it) free from taxes. By order of [Karā]mbichcheṭṭu1794 [Sarv]ādittaṉ, who belonged (?) to the sabhā, we,•••••••••• Bhaṭṭaṉ, Ma[l6a]ppirāṉ Kumārasāmi-Kramavittaṉ, Aruḷāḷa-Bhaṭṭaṉ1795 of Uṟuppuṭṭūr,1796 Śrīraṅga-nātha-Bhaṭṭaṉ of Paśumbuṟam, Śaṁkaranārāyaṇa-Bhaṭṭaṉ of Uṟuppuṭṭūr, Tillaikkūtta-Kramavittaṉ1797 of Kura[va]ś[ē]ri, and Dōṇaśūra-Kramavittaṉ1798 of Kirāñji,1799--all these members of the great assembly made and gave (this) writing [on stone, to last as long as] the moon and the sun.
(L. 17.) This is the writing of Vāṉavaṉmahādēvi-Uḍaiyāṉ Śelvaṉ Kul6aiñāṉ. This charity was made by me, Dēvandainādaṉ Aruḷāḷaṉ, alias Kulōttuṅga-Śōl6a-Māpodiyarāyaṉ,1800 of Rājarājapuram in Eyiṟkōṭṭam. This charity••••• •••••


No. 76.--INSCRIPTION IN THE JAMBUKESVARA TEMPLE.



This inscription (No. 31 of 1891) is engraved on the east wall of the second prākāra of the Jambukēśvara temple1801 on the island of Śrīraṅgam near Trichinopoly. As stated in Vol. II. p. 253, the ancient name of the locality is Tiruvāṉaikkā, i.e. 'the sacred elephant-grove,' and the name of the temple is derived from 'the sacred white jambū tree' (tiru-veṇ-ṇāval in Tamil). At the time of the inscription, Tiruvāṉaikkā belonged to Mīgōl6ai, a subdivision of the district of Pāṇḍikulāśani-vaḷanāḍu.1802
The date is the 47th year of the reign of Kulōttuṅga I. A certain Villavarāyaṉ had set up in the temple images of Ṛishabhavāhana, i.e. Śiva riding on the bull, and of Pārvatī. To provide for the requirements of these two images, he purchased from the temple authorities some land, whose crop of paddy had to be made over to the temple.


TEXT.

8 [ta]ñ[ci v]eru neLittoTi araNenappukka kATaRa[t]tuTai[t]tu nATTaTip-paTu[t]tu maRRa[va]r[ta]mmai van_a[cara]r tiriyum poccai veñ[cu]rameRRi koRRavija[ya]stampantic[ai]t[o]RuniRutti muttin cal[A]pamu[m] muttamiTpo-[ti]yiluma[ttav]eg[ka]ri [pa]Tu[ma]y-
9 yacca[y]yamugkanniyugkaikko[N]Tu pu[ni]tattennATTellai kATTi[kkuTa]malai[n]A-T[Tu]LLa cAv[e]Re[l]l[An]tani vicumpeRa [mA]veRiya tan1816varuta[ni]tta-lai[varaik]kuRukalar [ku]laiyakkoTTARuT[pa*]Ta neRi[t]oRum ni[lai]kaLiT-TaruLit[ti][Ra*]l [koL vi]-1817

12 vatti[ka]L SrIkulottug[ka]cozadEvark[ku] yA[N]Tu 47 Avatu pANTikulA-canivaLan[A]TTu1823mikozai dEvatAnabrahmateyam tiruvA[n_ai]k[k]Avil tiruve-N[NA]val1824kizinitama[r*]ntaruLiya [tribhu]van_a[pa]tikku1825mulabhRttyanAkiya [za]-1826

15 ykkAlukku vaTakkum mIpAr[k]kellai1829uttamacilicca[ru]ppetimagkalattu ten-[pi]TAkai putukku[Ti] ellaikku kizakkum vaTapArkkellai tennARRagkaraip-peruvazikku teRku Aka iv[vi]cainta perunA[n]kellai[yuL]paTTa nilam
16 4 nta [|*] innilam nAl[e] mukkAlum ittevarkku yA[N]Tu nARpat[te]- zAvatu varai [pa]yirili punceyyAykkuTTamu[ma]NNumiTTukkiTa[nta]maiyilannilam mu[n_ai]yan [a]rumozitevanA[n_a] villa[va]rA[yan_u]kku viRRu[kkuTu]t[tu]-

18 tu ivan uTaiyAr tiruvAn_aikkAvuTaiya emp[e]rumAn k[o]yili[l] iTag-[kai]nAyakarenRu1830 ezuntaruLuvitta iSabhav[A]han_adE[va]rkkum nampirATTi-yArkku tirumañ[cana]gkaLu[k]ku tiruvamirtupa[Tik]ku iraNTu tirunALi[lu]m i[ra]N[Tu] nAL tiruvizA ezuntaruLukaikku uL[Li][TTu*]
19 v[e]NTum nimantagkaLukku innila 4 nta kallittirutti SrIbhaNTArattu puncey varicai[y]Al veli onRukku nel aigkalamAka rAjakesa[ri]mara[k]kAlAl innilam nAle mukkAlu[k]kum aLappat[Ana] ja1831 23kaLa vata ga [|*] in-nel irupattumukkalane irutU[Ni][kkuRu*]-
20 Niyum aLakkumaTattil1832 kAr p[A]ti [pacAnam] pAti aLappatAkavum [|*] [i]ti[l] mikiti1833 ko[N]Tu [i]van iTagkainAyaka[ren]Ru ezu[nta]ruLu-vitta iSabhavAhanadEvarkkum nampirATTi[yA]rkkum tirumañcan_apaTika[Lu]k-[ku]m tiruva[mu]tupaTikkum ira[N]Tu tirunALilum [i]ra[NTu] nAL[e]zu-(La)ntaru[Luk][aikku*]
21 uLLiTTu ve[NTu]nimantagkaLukku nimantañceytu [kuTu]ttom [|*] mu[n_ai]yan [aru]m[ozi]t[eva]nA[n_a] villavarAya[nu]kku tiruvAn_aikkAvu[T]aiya ema-p[e]rumAnukku1834mulabhRttyanAkiya 1835zaNDEzvaran [u]L[LiT]Ta ka[nmi]kaLom [|*] itu panmAhEzvararakSai [||*]
[page 3-171]

TRANSLATION



(Line 11.) In the 47th year (of the reign) of king Rājakēsarivarman, alias the emperor of the three worlds, Śrī-Kulōttuṅga-Śōl6adēva, who etc.1836--(at) the order of Chaṇḍēśvara,1837 who is the chief servant of the lord of the three worlds who is pleased to reside under the sacred white jambū) tree (tiru-veṇ-ṇāval) at Tiruvāṉaikkā, a dēvadāna (and) brahmadēya in Mīgōl6ai, (a subdivision) of Pāṇḍikulāśani-vaḷanāḍu, we sold the following land to Muṉaiyaṉ Arumol6idēvaṉ, alias Villavarāyaṉ, the son of Arayaṉ of Vaḷambaguḍi in Mīśeṅgiḷi-nāḍu, (a subdivision) of Jayasiṁha-kulakālavaḷanāḍu.1838
(L. 13.) The eastern boundary agreed on of the land which (we) sold to him at Āḷiguḍi in Mīgōl6ai, (a subdivision) of Pāṇḍikulāśani-vaḷanāḍu, (one) among the villages on the southern bank (of the Kāvērī) (and) a dēvadāna of the lord Emberumāṉ of Tiruvāṉaikkā, (is) to the west of the Piḷḷaigoḷḷi) channel; the southern boundary (is) to the north of the Agai channel on the north of the thrashing-floor; the western boundary (is) to the east of the boundary of Pudukkuḍi, a hamlet on the south of Uttamaśīli-chaturvēdimaṅgalam;1839 (and) the northern boundary (is) to the south of the high road on the southern bank of the river. Altogether, 4(3/4) (vēli) of land, enclosed within these four great boundaries agreed on.
(L. 16.) As these four and three quarters (vēli) of land had been lying full of holes and sand as uncultivated dry land until the forty-seventh year (of the reign) of this king, we agreed to sell that land to Muṉaiyaṉ Arumol6idēvaṉ, alias Villavarāyaṉ, for a purchase-money of 4, 1/20, 1/80 good kāśu current at the time.
(L. 17.) Having received these four, one twentieth and one eightieth kāśu and having deposited (them) in the treasury of the temple of Emberumāṉ of Tiruvāṉaikkā, (we) sold (the land) to Muṉaiyaṉ Arumol6idēvaṉ, alias) Villavarāyaṉ.
(L. 18.) Having dug and reclaimed these 4(3/4) (vēli) of land, (he) has to supply for these four and three quarters (vēli) of land to the temple treasury 23 kalam, 2 tūṇi and 1 kuṟuṇi of paddy by the marakkāl (called after) Rājakēsarin,1840 (viz.) five kalam for each vēli at the rate for dry land, for the expenses required by the god Ṛishabhavāhana--whom he had set up under the name Iḍaṅgaināyagar1841 in the temple of the lord Emberumāṉ of Tiruvāṉaikkā--and by (his) consort, (viz). for bathing the idols, for oblations, for carrying them about on two days at (each of) the two festivals, &c.
(L. 19.) If those twenty-three kalam, two tūṇi and one kuṟuṇi of paddy are supplied, half has to be supplied in kār (and) half in paśāṉam.1842
(L. 20.) Having received this in full, we made provision for the expenses required by the god Ṛishabhavāhana whom he had set up under the name Iḍaṅgaināyagar, and by (his) consort, (viz). for bathing the idols, for oblations, for carrying them about on two days at (cach of) the two festivals, &c.
[page 3-172]
(L. 21.) (This is an agreement made by) us, the Pūjāris, including Chaṇḍēśvara, who is the chief servant of Emberumāṉ of Tiruvāṉaikkā, with Muṉaiyaṉ Arumol6i-dēvaṉ, alias Villavarāyaṉ. This (is placed under) the protection of all Māhēśvaras.


No. 77.--INSCRIPTION AT KAVANTANDALAM.



In chronological order this inscription follows immediately after No. 67 above, and No. 78 after No. 68 above. It was found impossible to insert them in their proper places, because Nos. 64 to 76 had been already set up in pages when Nos. 77 and 78 were copied. Besides these two records, the following inscriptions commencing with pukazmAtu viLagka were copied in 1901, in addition to those noted under clause VIII. on page 126 above:--
30. 36th year: Teṉṉēri, No. 195 of 1901.
31. 41st year: do. No. 197 of 1901.
32. 42nd year: Achcharapākkam, No. 254 of 1901.
33. 43rd year: do. No. 259 of 1901.
34. 49th year: do. No. 256 of 1901.
The subjoined inscription (No. 206 of 1901) is engraved on the south wall of the Lakshmīnārāyaṇa temple at Kāvāntaṇḍalam. The same temple contains three earlier inscriptions (Nos. 207 to 209 of 1901), according to which it was built in the time of the Gaṅga-Pallava king Kampavarman1843 by a certain Mānasarpa from Kuḷaṉūr1844 in Vēṅgai-nāḍu.
The inscription, which is incomplete, is dated in the 4th year of the reign of Rājēndra-Chōḷa II., but omits the reference to his queen which occurs in the Sōmaṅgalam inscription of the 3rd year (No. 67 above). It records the proceedings of a meeting of the assembly of Kāyvāṉtaṇḍalam (l. 3) in Tamaṉūr-nāḍu, a subdivision of the district of Ūṟṟukkāṭṭu-kōṭṭam Kāvāntaṇḍalam, Tamaṉūr1845 and Ūṟṟukkāḍu1846 are all included in the modern Conjeeveram tāluka.1847


TEXT



1 svasti SrI [||*] tiru ma[n_ni] viLagka i[ru]kuvaTan_aiya tan_ toLum vA-Lun_tu[Nai]yenakkezalar1848 vañcan_ai kaTa[ntu vayi]rAkarattukku[ñ]carakkuzAm pala vAri1849aiñcalic[ca]kkarakoTTattArAvaraican_aittikku nikazattiRai koNTaruLi arukkanutaiyatta(r)[ai]cai[yi]lirukku[m] kamalaman_aiya ni[la]makaTan_n_ai mun_nAL1850 kuLitta[va*]n_nAn_1851 tirumAlAkikkezalAkiyeTut[tan_a]1852 yAtuñcaliyA vakaiyini-teTuttu tan_ kuTai-

4 [n]tu [paNi]ppa paNiyARpaNi(y)[tta] e[zuttu] [|*] ik{??}•••••• ••• pu uLLArum nAgkaLum celut[ta*] m[A*]TTAtu kiTan_tamaiyil mah[A]sabhaiyom kaTavomAna [cittirai tiruvoNat]tiruviz[A*]••• •••••••


TRANSLATION.



(Line 2.) Hail ! Prosperity ! In the 4th year (of the reign) of king Rājakēsarivarman, alias the lord Śrī-Rājēndra-Śōl6adēva, who etc.1859--we, the great assembly of Kāyvāṉ-taṇḍalam, alias Chaturvēdimaṅgalam, a brahmadēya in Tamaṉūr-nāḍu, (a sub-division) of Ūṟṟukkāṭṭu-kōṭṭam, (a district) of Jayaṅgoṇḍa-Śōl6a-maṇḍalam, being assembled, without a vacancy in the assembly,1860 in the court (muṟṟam) of the sacred temple of Vīṟṟirund-Āl6vār in the middle of our village on a Thursday which corresponded to (the day of) Tiruvōṇam (Śravaṇa) and to the sixth tithi of the first fortnight of the month of Vṛśchika in this year,1861 ordered (the following) writing, while the magistrate (adhikāṛn) Śōl6a-Mūvēndavēḷār1862 also was walking about.
(L. 4.) Whereas•••••••••• and ourselves had been unable to pay•••••••••• which was due from us, the great assembly, [at] the festivals (on the days) of Śittirai (and) Tiruvōṇam••••••••••


No. 78.--INSCRIPTION AT PERUMBER.



This inscription (No. 264 of 1901) is engraved on the west wall of a maṇḍapa in front of the Tāndōṉṟīśvara temple at Perumbēr in the Madurāntakam tāluka of the Chingleput district. The ancient name of the temple was Śrīkaraṇīśvara (l. 22), and that of the village was Perumbēṟūr (ll. 22 and 23). From this and other inscriptions we learn that Śrī-Madurāntaka-chaturvēdimaṅgalam, which is the modern Madurāntakam, formed a separate division of the district of Kaḷattūr-kōṭṭam1863 (l. 21); that Achcharapākkam (9 miles south-south-west of Madurāntakam) was a quarter of it; and that Perumbēṟūr (3 miles south-west of Achcharapākkam) was a hamlet on the south of it (l. 22).
[page 3-174]
The date is the 11th year of the reign of Kulōttuṅga I. (l. 20 f.). As stated in the introductory remarks to this chapter (p. 129 f.), the inscription carries the account of the king's achievements as far as the defeat of Vikkalaṉ and the conquest of Gaṅga-maṇḍalam and Śiṅgaṇam. It records that the assembly of Madurāntakam remitted the taxes on certain land at Perumbēṟūr in favour of the temple, and breaks off with the signatures of a number of citizens in charge of different portions (śēri) of the city, which were named after Chōḷa kings.
To the list of inscriptions opening with pukaz cUznta puNari on p. 125 f. the following one, which I had overlooked, must be added:--
16. 15th year: Kaḍappēri near Madurāntakam, No. 138 of 1896.


TEXT.
